reviewText:
Do you like comics?
Do you like atmosphere?
Do you like having two demonic tentacle heads protruding from your back that allow you to whip, grab, dismember, and look bad ♥♥♥?

Welcome to The Darkness 2.

The single player campaign is not too long depending on difficulty level and your level of expertise, but I found the story and atmosphere so refined that I thoroughly enjoyed my play through and recommended it. Also of note is the Vendettas campaign. There is a 4 player online co-op that intertwines with the single player story filling in some back story. Overall Vendettas is a fun diversion with friends but a little repetitive. You don't get to play as the main character Jackie, instead one of a set of four mercenaries that each have a personal weapon infused with Dark Essence.

Now for the gameplay. The Darkness II finally disproves the theory that developers have to leave the main protagonist as hollow as possible in first person shooters so that the gamers can fully immerse themselves. This is just lazy storytelling and don't let anyone tell you differently. The Darkness is a game of two parts. Light and dark. Players experience the tender heart of Jackie when he is around Jenny and Aunt Sarah. But then players go out and start shooting guys and flinging fan blades at them with one demon arm while decapitating them with the other demon arm. In The Darkness II you quad-wield and your survival depends on it. At first it can seem a bit much to keep track of, grabbing things and throwing things and slashing and shooting all at once. But once you learn to multitask you will feel like a God. It's intoxicating. The Darkness becomes an extension of your will and soon you are slaying rooms full of enemies with gleeful abandon. There is an upgrade system to tailor the combat to your preferences and the point system that pays for your new abilities will encourage you to perform gruesome executions. The game is bloody. But due to a smart move on the developer's behalf, the cell-shaded comic style graphics make all the gore less disgusting. This time around the enemies have their own supernatural weapons at their disposal, a noted improvement over the last game.

Inside all of us there's a violent beast that needs to be sated, lets it bleed over into our real lives. This game does just that. Incredibly violent, and intensely satisfying. My only wish is that it were longer. Great fun; A must have.

I do not like shooters. Yes, you read it well. And I'm not a fan of super power/super heroes/action games. Add to these that the game is short and linear. It doesn't look ugle but its picture is not modern even for 2012-year-game at the same time. And yeah, it's buggy. And, please, take into your account that it is almost the end of the 2014, November, almost 3 years since the game release.

And I've finished it. And I liked it as this game has the most interesting part that beats others weaknesses - its story line. It keeps you to the end like an addictive movie. Like a movie you want to recommend to your friends after all. It's almost 3 years since this game release and it still can be recommended.

I also like this game has skill trees. You won't be able to get all skills but, well, you don't need all of them anyway =) Are you tired with shooting your enemies? Smash them with snakes, throws a chair or grab somebody by his leg. Despite of serious story and bloody scenes a gameplay can be very funny and relaxing.

Last thing I wanted to mention is characters. They are well-made. You won't meet a lot of dialogs but you will feel each character as individual with its own identity. Many games have NPCs you pass like strangers and never come back or remember them. I remember all characters from this game and they supplement the plot and the gameplay.

Thank you for your time and have a good play!

reviewText:
n a strange coincidence I started playing The Darkness II at about roughly the same time I started Alan Wake. The plots in each game revolve heavily on light and darkness, which is really just a play on the classic good vs. evil conflict. In Alan Wake the protagonist uses light as a weapon to destroy and evade evil, but in The Darkness II the protagonist depends on the darkness to literally envelop himself in evil to defeat enemies, becoming the monstrous “host” of the Darkness.

Jackie Estacado, Don of the Franchetti family, has laid low with the Darkness bottled up for two years following the death of his girlfriend Jenny. After a failed attempt on his life, Jackie is ready to unleash the Darkness once again, to exact revenge and to continue fighting for Jenny. His new enemies have been tracking him for years, and their leader, Victor Valente, is after the Darkness for himself. Jackie also faces a reality problem, not knowing if what he is experiencing is real while having several brief visions of a psychiatric ward throughout the game.

Before I continue I’d first like to include a precautionary note. The Darkness II is definitely what I’d refer to as an adult oriented game. The entire thing revolves around harnessing evil for violence, has many demonic themes (eating hearts of dead enemies to regain health, collecting dark relics for points, etc.), includes adult themes, and is not something I’d ever buy for a kid. With the appropriate rating there’s nothing wrong that. I’m not discounting the game for this at all, but the “dark” themes turned me off a bit, and I’d guess that reactions to these themes among FPS fans would be mixed.

With that note out of the way, I’d like to continue with an annoyance. Game assistants, such as Wheatly in Portal 2, seem to be popping up more and more these days. The inclusion of the Darkling in The Darkness II was fine functionally, but it seemed like the character was intended to appeal to a younger audience, which didn’t make much sense to me. For example, there were several times where the Darkling would run up to an enemy’s body I had just killed to pass gas or urinate on it. If you’re making an adult game, I just don’t quite understand why you would include something like this. The Darkling just seemed too offensive to me; I wasn’t able to appreciate the character at all. I also feel like the horror element to the game would have been enhanced if the player were forced to play alone.

On the positive side I’d say that despite playing on rails, The Darkness II is a fairly solid and intense first-person shooter. I didn’t encounter any bugs or gameplay issues, and there were plenty of enemies to kill. Locales were mixed, and even though I found it a bit cliché, the vacant carnival level was definitely an enjoyable setting. There weren’t exactly a large variety of weapons, but the inclusion of the ability tree, in which new abilities can be purchased with dark essence points, helped. The abilities tree seemed like kind of an afterthought on the whole, but it’s better than just having generic weapons. Items such as extended gun clips, a swarm distraction to stun enemies, and better weapon handling can be purchased in the abilities tree. The Darkness itself is really the most powerful weapon, which can destroy enemies in a couple of swipes if they’re close enough. When things got crazy and I was surrounded by enemies the Darkness always seemed to allow me to break out; it was pretty incredible to use.

Another strong point of The Darkness II was the voice acting. It wasn’t all great, but I was especially impressed with David Hoffman’s portrayal of the half deranged occultist Johnny Powell (example trailer linked) and Brian Bloom as the new voice of Jackie. The loading segments in which each of these characters reveal more of the storyline were some of the most memorable portions of the game. Voice acting in video games can vary quite a bit, and it’s not usually very good; this game is definitely an exception. Sound effects and music were also decent.

Visuals were also a positive, but you shouldn’t go into it expecting total realism. The Darkness II was developed using cel-shaded animation, which is different from the first game. The cel-shading was different than what I have seen before in that it was subtle and at times almost unnoticeable. There was definitely a nice balance between realism and animation, which really made it seem as if I was experiencing the graphic novel on which the game is based.

In terms of difficulty, I’d have to say that I didn’t find The Darkness II overly challenging. The AI was easy to avoid and fool for the most part, but there were a few portions that I had to replay several times to finally move forward. Being equipped with the Darkness felt as if I was much more powerful than the majority of the enemies.

In addition to the single-player campaign The Darkness II also includes a Vendetta mode in which you can carry out missions for Jackie as one of four characters with special powers. These missions can be played alone or in co-op mode, but the Vendettas are definitely not the main attraction. It’s one of those extra things thrown in that you try once or twice but to which you never come back.

Overall, I’d say that The Darkness II is a decent shooter, but there is nothing in it that is amazing; it’s respectable but mostly predictable. Playing a more or less “evil” character felt different compared to all the other standard “save the Earth” games, but other than the Darkness it doesn’t include much that hasn’t been done before. The story and voice acting is a big plus. The main campaign isn’t that long, and the AI isn’t the greatest, but it is intense and still enjoyable if you’re an FPS fan.

reviewText:
AT A GLANCE(Full review follows below)

Game Name: The Darkness II
Original Release: 2012
Genre Tags: FPS; Dark; Action; Psychological; Story Rich
My Overall Grade: A-
Estimated Playtime (Campaign): 6-18 hours
Multiplayer Aspect: Auxiliary
Recommended To: Established fans of the genre; Those intrigued by the genre; Strong narrative advocates; Game atmosphere connoisseurs
REVIEWThe Darkness II is an action FPS with strong narrative elements and a stylish, graphic-noir atmosphere.  The gameplay feels both familiar and fresh simultaneously, while the characters and story keep the player engaged and interested.  Also, the addition of an XP system and skill-trees allow the player to continue to work towards new goals and to customize their character according to their preferred combat style.  All of these elements mesh together to create a very enjoyable game that I feel all but the most extremely discerning gamers should appreciate.

One of the most intriguing aspects of The Darkness II is the story, and the characters that make it.  The twisted and confused thoughts of the main character set the tone of the game from the first level, and evolve as the story progresses, in a similar fashion to games like Max Payne and Alan Wake.  The auxiliary characters are diverse and interesting, enticing the player to initiate optional conversations. The narrative is a perfect blend of mafia drama and psychological thriller that should enthrall anyone who enjoys being told a good story.

The actual gameplay experience is also exquisite.  The combination of familiar FPS aspects with some well-integrated novelty goes a long way to make the game downright fun.  There are various guns and abilities to use to wreak havoc on your enemies during action-packed fight sequences.  Additionally, the XP and skill-point system will keep you goal-oriented and allow you to unlock new abilities as you play to keep things fresh.

For those itching for more after beating the main campaign, there is also an entirely separate Co-op Mode, which expands upon the universe of The Darkness II and allows for multiplayer gameplay.  Fortunately, all the missions in the Co-op Mode can be completed in solo play if you don’t want to spend time trying to find others to play with.  While not quite as pristine as the main campaign, it adequately provides some supplementary gameplay to a game that would otherwise be only medium-length (in terms of total hours).

In summary, I posit that The Darkness II is a superb all-around game with many positive elements contributing to its overall quality.  I would say it is a pretty safe bet for most gamers who have a broad taste for games, and a definite safe bet for those gamers who enjoy FPS games and interesting narratives.  Expect about 6-18 hours of gameplay, depending on how much of a “completionist” you are.  If you can get it for a price you are comfortable with, it is definitely worth the pick-up.

reviewText:
It doesn't take you long to be pulled into the story. The Darkness 2 does a great job of immersing you into the feelings and thoughts of the main character, which is a rarity in modern day gaming. Often you are very disconected from the story and the emotions of the characters. Lately, the only other game I have played that did such a great job of pulling you in, emotionally, was BioShock Infinite.

Beyond the story, which while nothing especially impressive, what is there is enough and is well orcestrated. The most impressive feat is the game's ability to put you in the shoes of the main character and really doubt what is real and what is not real (in the game).

The gameplay is top notch though and if you enjoy shooters where you run from one area to the next and have to clear all the waves of enemies, then this is a game for you. The gunplay is fun and has impact and the tentacles are well implemented so that they are not overpowered and yet are still very fun and exciting to use.
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=304584465
I found myself using primarily guns but definitely had to use my powers frequently to stay in the fight. I was glad though that the powers did not dominate the gameplay so that you simply use the powers when you feel the need and are not forced to constantly use the powers. In some games where you have powers they dominate the other gameplay mechanics to the point that you find yourself only using the powers and nothing else. Fortunately, this is not the case in the Darkness 2.
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=304361429

The graphics are not impressive or special, but they make up for what they lack in the style, which once you've played the game to completion the style will make sense. A lot of people were surprised when they first revealed the first gameplay video of The Darkness 2 because of the art style they had used. But there is a definite reason for it and it only further helps immerse you into the world of confusion that the main character is living in.
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=304361384
The soundtrack is great and the voice work is top quality. All in all, it is a very fun game with a decent story that manages to pull you in and leaves you desiring more.

Would definitely recommend giving this game a spin! It is a great purchase and a great experience to play through once or even twice! In addition there are even some co-op missions to further the experience, so if you have a friend to play it with it will add a few more hours of quality gameplay.

reviewText:
The Darkness 2
Rating 8/10
Overview: Underrated First Person Shooter

The Good:

+ Cell shaded graphics

+ The game has a strong narrative which holds the game together otherwise it would turn into a mindless shooter. Although the plot itself is pretty basic the developers did a great job of presenting the story. The characters may be stereotypical of what you would expect in a mafia however it doesn't take away the fact they are believable and expertly voiced.

+ The game features a variety of guns which is what you would expect from any first person shooter however the twist in this game is that you have two demonic arms, one for picking/throwing objects and the other as a high powered melee weapon. You can also execute enemies in some pretty horrific ways.

+ Speaking of gratuitous violence, it works well in this game. Most games have over the top violence just for the sake of it yet I feel this game really nailed this particular aspect, it really sells the notion that you are possessed by dark forces.

+ Killing enemies and collecting relics in the levels allows you to level up different skills among 4 skill trees.

+ New Game + allows you to replay the game with all your acquired skills

+ Easy Achievements, minimal grinding required.

+ Great voice acting

+ Good soundtrack


The Average:

On the one hand the game is short, roughly 5-7 hours in length. On the other hand the game isn't bogged down with pointless filler either, the game does what it wants to without over extending its welcome.

After you complete the main story, you can try the vendetta campaign, an add on to extend your playtime. You can choose between 4 characters, each with their own weapon, skill trees and powers. You can also play co-op with friends. The problem however is that every level becomes very repetitive of killing wave after wave of enemy. The formula wears itself out very early on. This mode is also very short , roughly 2-3 hours in length.

The Bad:

- Multiplayer is dead



Conclusion

It was a sequel that didn't need to be made but in the end it turned out to be a great game to a very underappreciated game franchise. A fun distraction while it lasts and nothing more. Strongly recommend at a discount price.

reviewText:
I doubt that you have ever heard of 2006's console exclusive the Darkness or the comic books published by Top Cow Productions (yes, that's the actual name... I couldn't make that one up) of the same name, so let me tell you a little bit about the unpopular The Darkness II.
Or The Darkness 2 if you don't know your Roman numerals. If you don't, shame on you.

In The Darkness II you play as Jackie Estacado, a member of the Franchetti crime family. He was adopted by the former Don of the Franchetti's, Frankie Franchetti at the age of six and matured quickly; he lost his virginity to a female officer durning an investigation at the age of fourteen and killed his first victim at the age of sixteen. His presence in the Franchetti family helped it to expand, as predicted by the mysterious Sonatine.
When Jackie turned twenty-one, he revieved the powers of the Darkness, a timeless power allowing the Host to form basically anything out of darkness (for example, the Arms) that will crumble to dust in the light. To keep it short, lots of sh*t hit the fan in a short period of time, causing his true love Jenny to be killed.
Years passed since then, and Jackie forced himself to keep the Darkness locked up inside of him after blaming it for Jenny's death.
That's where the second game begins and the Darkness gets unleashed again.
Sound interresting? Well trust me, it IS interresting.

The Good:
· Very solid shooter mechanics.
· An upgrade-system that will make you feel more powerful as the game progresses.
· You can control Jackie's sentient demon arms to grab enemies and objects and perform brutal finishing moves. (For example splitting a guy clean in half or ripping someone's spine out of his sh*tter. I know. His f*cking sh*tter. They just rip that open harder than Kim Kardashian's c*nt.)
· A surprisingly personal and meaningful story that will keep you interrested until the very end.
· The Darkness 2 plays with light in a unique way - standing in light will blind you and make you more volnurable, but being in the darkness makes you brutally strong.

The Bad:
· The co-op missions can easily be forgotten.
· Besides tha campaign, collectibles and co-op the game offers too little content to keep you coming back to it.
· Unfortunately unsuccesful, meaning that the chances of a third installment is highly unlikely.

The Ugly:
While the comicbook-esque and gore-filled visuals are a joy to look at, there's nothing too stunning about it. It never looks bad, but it doesn't look as good as it could have.

Final verdict:
This is a title I will always remember for its dark and unique setting, plus it's one of the forgotten good comicbook games" out there that needs to be played
date: simply because it's an thrilling experience. 8.5/10"

reviewText:
The Darkness II is a fun arcade shooter with a bunch of supernatural abilities thrown into the mix. The graphics are bright and cartoonish, similar to 2K Games' more popular game Borderlands, and don't tax a modern gaming PC overmuch. Unfortunately, there is no option to disable depth of field, which is not to everyone's taste.

The gameplay is varied, enabling you to deploy different tactics ranging from brutal executions using your extra demon snake arms and impaling people with thrown parking meters to channelling the darkness into your guns as you shred the enemies stunned by your swarms of demonic flies.

Controls are fair, but your demon arms suffer from a complete inability to multitask, preventing you from, for example, eating the hearts of fallen enemies to regain health while simultaneously holding a makeshift javelin or a shield at the ready, because such petty concerns are beneath your right hand, which is only used for striking. The game also assumes that if you have a gamepad connected to your PC, you will only be using it, refusing to stop vibrating it and displaying gamepad-centric button prompts even if you play the game using the keyboard and mouse exclusively, so be prepared to have to unplug or disable your gamepad if you prefer keyboard and mouse.

The story is a little on the short side, but the co-op enabled side missions called Vendettas" make up for it. The world is well-designed and some of the dialogue is very funny if you take the time to listen to it. The game gives you the ability to skip most cutscenes and dialogue

reviewText:
After getting 100% on it, I should probably make a review of it.
The Darkness 2 is an extremely violent FPS with a storyline that twists and turns and gives you even more addiction at the end game. This is one of the better storylines that I have ever played and it gives you all the feels in all the right ways. You get joy, revenge, sadness, vengance, longing, and all those other characteristics to be able to relate with everyone in the game.
The Darkness was an interesting concept because it isn't a voice that is just narrating you or such. It is a part of you and influences you. It doesn't tell you to go here or there, it screams at you that your will obey it and it taunts you with a lost soul it controls.
The boss fights in the game are pretty solid, the bosses have enough mobility to where you can't just stand there and shoot at them in one direction. They move a lot and most of the time you have to be moving as well.
The light concept is very well done and brings more aspects of thinking ahead and getting priorities out (especially in the harder difficulties). If you are under a light source your screen goes white where you can barely see and being in the light removes your powers and any buffs that you have acquired that only apply when you are in the dark. So when a van comes crushing through towards you, you should probably shoot out the headlights first before trying to fend off the enemies.
The execution moves are super brutal. There are 4 different executions that you can do and each results in a different buff and also a different execution style. You can either use the execution to restore health, restore ammo, gain a demonic riot shield, or shorten you skills timers. Each I believe have 3 different executions resulting in 12 total executions which all have their own amount of brutality for anyone to enjoy.
There is enough of a talent tree to make you play more than one run through and probably just move on to Don difficulty at that point. You can do New Game+ to keep all your talents and such, which makes a considerable amount of Don difficulty pretty easy, but bosses still can be hard to beat.
I know that some people didn't really like the graphics of the game, but I believe they probably made them that way because of the Borderlands series, both are made by 2K games, so I think that is what they did, but in my own opinion I love the graphics as do I love Borderlands, so it was enjoyable for me.
The NPCs in the game all have a certain human flair to them where they aren't just NPCs, you can relate to them easily and they become much more than just NPCs.
You collect relics throughout the game that will give you essence (which is gained by killing people, getting relics, and is used to buy talents) and they aren't that hard to find. Some are easy to miss but generally you won't have problems finding them.
The weapon selection through the game is pretty small, but they made it for a good reason. There aren't any snipers or rocket launchers or big weapons like that, no grenades either (unless you count throwing propane tanks XD ). with the smaller weapons, you can either weild one at a time, or dual weild. The choices are for single shots: Desert Eagle, Cobra, and M9. The choices are for automatics: UMP5, MP7, and Micro UZI. The choices are for the main weapon: Carbine (M16 Burst Fire), AK47, Sawed Off Shotgun, Model 1887 (?), and a Stiker.
The powers you have through the game is also limited, but they are super powerful so it doesn't really matter at that point honestly. You have two activated abilities, The Swarm and Gun Channeling. The Swarm goes out and swarms around people effectively stunning them (and sometimes even killing them), you can get upgrades for it to last longer, recharge faster and affect more enemies. Gun Channgeling gives you infinite ammo and super powered shots for a limited time. The upgrades consits of longer lasting, faster recharge, auto shooting towards targets and shooting through walls. So as you can tell, turning a corridor full of enemies you can just activate both and blow through them both in two seconds.
I didn't really find any bugs in the game. The only real problem I had is that sometimes the screen goes a little blurry, like the beginning of being of barely stepping in light and it just causes some depth of view problems. It doesn't really last long if it happens, but it can and when you are trying to fight people it messes with your vision a bit.
So all in all to say: 10/10 hands down. Would love to have harder achievements though.

reviewText: If you've played the first game, you'll know that you're going to be running around with the powers of The Darkness before long, and you're going to feel like a complete badass. In this game, however, you have all of your powers from the start, and so if you're on the easiest level or the hardest, you're going to tear every enemy apart with ease. Rarely did I actually use my guns, opting more to rip my enemies to pieces with all of the combo kills. The story is very twisted here, and by the end of the game, you start questioning the game's reality, debating which portion of the game is real and which is the illusion. I highly recommend this, and if you can get a friend or two to play with you, the co-op even continues the story as a side note, letting you see what happens with your crew when you're not around to tie up all the loose ends. It's on sale for 80% off this weekend-- letting a $30 game go when it's $6 would be a shame.\n\nIf you want a taste of the awesomeness, try the demo-- it's available for download from this page.

reviewText:
The Darkness 2 continua a história do Jack Estacado, um chefe da máfia que possui poderes sobrenaturais, graças à entidade denomidada ''The Darkness''!

História: Para quem jogou o primeiro jogo, provavelmente vai ser um festival de nostalgia, ainda mais porque ele foi um dos primeiros da ''next-gen'' passada (Xbox 360 e PS3). No segundo game, que se passa dois anos após o primeiro, você deverá salvar a alma de Jenny (SPOILERS!!!!! Sua ex-namorada falecida, que morreu no primeiro game).

Gameplay: O game volta com o sistema muito parecido do anterior, usando pistolas, 12s e metralhadoras para devastar os seus inimigos. Ele também usa os poderes do The Darkness, que seriam aquelas duas serpentes devoradoras de corações, que ficam acima de seu ombro.

Gráficos: O jogo está muito bonito, apesar do uso de cell-shading, que seria aquele mesmo motor gráfico do Borderlands, que geralmente não agrada muito. O design artístico do  game está excelente, valorizando a sua parte de revista em quadrinhos, já que o game foi inspirado no comic book ''The Darkness''.

Conclusão: The Darkness 2 é um game que faz jus ao seu antecessor, deixando a história um pouquinho de lado e focando mais no gameplay. Mas, o primeiro, na minha opinião, ainda é melhor!
Nota: 8.0!

reviewText:
NOTE: I have not played The Darkness 1. So my review can't compare the two games, I have however read the comic and know what happens, so my knowledge of the story is pretty decent.

A fan of The Darkness comic book, I picked up this game a while ago in a humble bundle, and really just didn't like the idea of having the demon arms and everything in the game. In fact, I would have ended up never playing it if I hadn't felt a commitment to the comics.
I decided to just play a single level this morning and actually found it fairly boring at first. The gameplay just seemed to be far too easy and the storyline was not what I had hoped for considering the excellent comic it was based on. I decided to play another level just to see if the game would pick up.
I ended up completing the game without stopping. It's amazing.
The gameplay works far better than I imagined. The demon arms are not tedious to use, and are not as overpowered as I felt they were in the first mission. Even without the demon arms, this would be a pretty solid FPS. However these of course add a unique twist on the game to seperate it from the countless other first person shooters available right now.

The storyline is fantastic for a AAA game. (I don't know if its a ''AAA'' game as it's release wasnt absolutely huge...Let's call it a ''AA''.)

If I am completely honest, the gameplay does get slightly repetitive. However this combined with the other flaw which is that the game is far too short, mean that you don't get bored of the game that easily as it's finished before you can get tiresome.
I don't feel like there's much replay value here unfortunately.

Final Verdict:
+Fantastic storyline.
+Entertaining gameplay
+Interesting use of demonic powers at the same time as guns. Something completely refreshing.
- Game is far too short
-Can become slightly repetitive towards the end. (However storyline gets more intense towards the end so you don't notice this so much.)
8/10

reviewText:
-Quick Review-
The Darkness II is a FPS with a lot of unique mechanics that I've only experienced for the first time in playing a game  with this  genre (grabbing stuff with tentacles, using them to heal yourself, I can hear a bad hentai joke coming...)
-Detailed breakdown review-
Story:  You play the game as Jackie, a gruff, angry, imposing man whom has a dark power that he inherited from his father. Tormented by his memory of his girl friend Jenny he struggles to try to get revenge for an attempt on his life.
I found it amusing that the game basically makes Jackie a crime boss, it game the game and the story an interesting tone. And the game carried it very well. The story was extremely well executed down to the very end of the game. I don't want to give anymore away, I will say that the game lets you select an introduction that explains what happened in the first Darkness game, if you (like me) never played the first game.

Game Play: while I was playing I was confused at the key mapping from the start of the game, but I picked up on the controls really quickly, like I've said I've only played the easiest difficulty so I just hack and slashed my way through the whole game and didn't die once.
There are a few main combat mechanics: 1) you use guns. Hence why I categorize it as a FPS 2) You have two shadow arms that wreak havoc with basic swing attacks 3) your shadow arms can grab and throw objects 4) your arms can grab other humans and mutilate them to gain ammo, health, amusement, etc.
By combining these various moves and abilities you can create some really awesome combination attacks. If you're aware of your surroundings and have good reflexes the game is really fun to play. I get tired of playing the same type of game over and over, but this game takes a great spin on traditional FPS's and gives it interesting mechanics to make the game just that much more interesting and engaging.
One more note on game play: Progression. I find that just killing hundreds of npc's for the sake of killing npc's isn't very interesting *cough cough* Brutal Legend *cough cough*. Anyway, the game has a level system that you can spent points to get new abilities, making that mass slaughter I had, actually have a purpose.

Achievements: As usual this game has the standard you beat the game" achievements. The "beat the game on this difficulty" achievements. there are also a few multiplayer achievements (which I haven't worked on yet)

The achievements seem straightforward. But I haven't earned them all yet (08/09/14) so I don't know if there are any really note worthy achievements at this time. but so far the achievements look very straightforward.

reviewText:
Short version
If you like FPS games in general Darkness II is a good choice, and if you're a fan of Top Cow comics, then it's a must buy.

Long version
The Darkness 2 is a FPS based on the highly successful comic series published by Top Cow.

You play as Jackie Estacado, leader of a New York mafia and the current host of the Darkness, an ancient force that's been passed down from generation to generation in the Estacado family.
(Note: The Darkness is one of the 3 ancient entities in the Top Cow universe, the other 2 being the Angelus - pure light- and the Witchblade - balance between light and dark.)
The game picks up where the prequel ended: Jenny, Jackie's lover is dead, and the mourning Jackie has repressed the Darkness. But when a mysterious organization, The Brotherhood is planning on eliminating Jackie and his organization and take the Darkness from him, he has no choice but to use the Darkness again to save himself. Sounds cheesy, I know.

The game features a quad-wielding system, which means you can wield 2 different weapons, while the 2 demonic tendrils can be used to grab objects to shield yourself, or throw, or to execute enemies.
As the host of the Darkness, Jackie has access to large variety of demonic abilites, however becoming vulnerable and blinded when exposed to light. This adds interesting elements to the gameplay: as you kill enemies you gain darkness essense, which can be used to learn new skills, becoming extremely strong. While Jackie's weakness to the light still forces the player to take cover and take out light sources constantly.

The game has good looking cel-shaded graphics, and there's enough variety in the level designs to keep the player entertained throughout the story. Although the game doesn't have huge levels, hence not much exploration and the secrets can be found fairly easy too.

Overall The Darkness II is a good FPS game, with solid gameplay and an interesting story with some psychological elements and a nice plot twist in the end, that imply a possible sequel.

PROS
- Nice looking cell-shaded graphics.
- 2 parallel campaigns: a single player storyline and a co-op campaign, showing the plot from different point of view.
- Psychological aspect of the story.
- Memorable characters.
- Good variety of abilities.
- Excellent voice acting.
- Large arsenal, ranging from firearms, through various projectiles to Darkness abilities.

CONS
- Extremely short, and sometimes painfully cheesy story.
- Not challanging enough: game can be beaten fairly easy even on highest difficulty.
- Execution animations are glitchy sometimes.

reviewText:
I'll start by saying i really enjoyed the first Darkness game. The story was really well done and the game had an atmoshpere of darkness and despair that really matched it. While this sequel is a decent game it didn't quite live up to it's predecessor for me.

First of all the game's cel-shaded looking visuals while not bad looking, just didn't seem to fit with this game. What should be quite a dark game ends up looking cartoony and it just isn't the right fit. It also makes the game feel a bit more arcadey instead of the visceral feel the gameplay of the first game had.

The story while interesting didn't reall captivate me as much as in the first game either and Jackie is also less likeable (though you could argue this might be to reflect the effect of the experiences in the first game on him.)

The gameplay and combat isn't too bad. There's a bit more variety with combat in this game and your darkling follower can be quite useful and adds a bit of comical relief. There's also more variety with enemies which require different strategies to deal with.

Overall all it's a decent game but nowhere near as good as it's predecessor. If you enjoyed the first game i'd say maybe give this one a go if you can pick it up cheap but but be prepared for the fact that it's not as good. If you didn't like the first you probably won't like this either. It's a 6/10 for me.

Ingredients:
1 1/2 cups all-purpose flour
3 tablespoons sugar
1 tablespoon baking powder
1/4 teaspoon salt
1/8 teaspoon freshly ground nutmeg
2 large eggs, at room temperature
1 1/4 cups milk, at room temperature
1/2 teaspoon pure vanilla extract
3 tablespoons unsalted butter, plus more as needed

Now to make it
1. In a large bowl, whisk together the flour, sugar, baking powder, salt, and nutmeg.
2. In another bowl, beat the eggs and then whisk in the milk and vanilla.
3. Melt the butter in a large cast iron skillet or griddle over medium heat.
4. Whisk the butter into the milk mixture. Add the wet ingredients to the flour mixture, and whisk until a thick batter is just formed
5. Keeping the skillet at medium heat, ladle about 1/4 cup of the batter onto the skillet, to make a pancake. Make 1 or 2 more pancakes, taking care to keep them evenly spaced apart. Cook, until bubbles break the surface of the pancakes, and the undersides are golden brown, about 2 minutes. Flip with a spatula and cook about 1 minute more on the second side. Serve immediately or transfer to a platter and cover loosely with foil to keep warm. Repeat with the remaining batter, adding more butter to the skillet as needed.
6. Procedure for adding fruit to pancakes: Once the bubbles break the surface of the pancakes, scatter the surface with sliced or diced fruit, or chocolate chips, nuts, etc. Flip with a spatula and cook for 1 minute more, being careful not to burn toppings.

reviewText:
I’m Jackie Estacado and I am the host for the Darkness. It’s a rough life fighting it from taking me over completely but man does it have some sweet powers. There has been some bad consequences though like losing the love of my life Jenny. I’m dealing with that and now some brotherhood wants to take the Darkness from me. Not going to happen on my watch.

In the Darkness II you are still suffering from the loss of Jenny from the first game. You have held the Darkness at bay for a while but now some group called the Brotherhood wants to take it from you using a device called the siphon which will suck the Darkness out of you. Well you aren’t going to let this happen because it’s just bad news for everyone.

There are a variety of ways to play through the levels fighting the Brotherhood. You can quad-wield now unlike the first game which gives you options like rip a car door off and use it as a shield while still being able to carry two guns and whip people with you other Darkness tentacle. Special executions can be done by grabbing an enemy with the tentacles, while he is stunned, and rip them apart for more health or ammo. You can also upgrade your powers via a skill tree wheel to add more possibilities like an execution that makes a shield from the enemy or had a Darkness swarm which stuns enemies for a short time.

Unlike the first game you only have one Darkling to help you but he has more of a personality than before. He adds a little humor to everything which lightens the dark mood a bit. Guns are your standard fair ranging from pistols, smgs, assault rifles, and shotguns. You can upgrade you guns to buy adding bigger clips, faster reloads, and shooting Darkness essence through them.

The game does look good most of the time with its comic book pastel art style. Environments seemed to be pretty bland though and felt like I was just going through a reskinned map each level. Enemies were also basic with pretty much the same five skins all the time.

Story wise I wasn’t too impressed and sometimes felt like I was just pushing forward to finish the game so it was no longer in my backlog. I just felt like it was just missing something the whole time. The endings, there are two choices, were both mediocre and not fulfilling. Expected a bigger finish than it was. You can replay it again in new game+ which lets you keep all your unlocked powers. I just didn’t feel the pull to do it though.

Darkness II also has a co-op campaign mode called Vendetta you can play with up to four players. It’s basically a side story to the campaign where you can control your choice of four different characters who have their own special Darkness powers. All these characters also have skills you can upgrade to make them more powerful. There is another mode you can pick through Vendetta called The Hit List which is basically shorter missions using the Vendetta campaign levels. Both these modes are cool to play with some friends but doesn’t really add much to the game.

Overall if you’re a fan of the comic and enjoyed the first Darkness then you’ll want to check this one out. It could have been much more without the co-op stuff and just focused on the single player portion of the game but it is still a decent game to play.

reviewText:
The Darkness II is a hidden gem of film noir in color. Not that it's good or not-bad, just unpopular.

You play as Jackie, an twenty-something who tries to avenge and save his girlfriend (?) Jenny. Other than that, I honestly cannot tell you what happens, it's just a sloppy and boring story.

The game heavily relies on staying in the darkness/shade as the title implies. Jackie is infested with some sort of demonic being that helps" him in finding Jenny. The demon can only manifest itself in the dark during which you can have many special skills and abilities involving guns and long tentacles. These abilities are used to kill various out-of-this-world devilish foes. I would say that it's a FPS run and gun by all means with a very creepy story.

It's a very unique game by all means.

The only problem I can really say is the shortness. You can finish this game in about 3 hour's time. That's very steep for a $30 price tag.

The Darkness II runs very well on my PC too

reviewText:
It's strange how sometimes you can like a game the first 10 minutes, see yourself hate it thoroughly after playing 30 minutes, almost giving the entire game up, and in the end love it so much it's end up on your favorites games list... The Darkness II is NOT that type of game. The first game however, is definitely that type of game. After a slow start and what seems to be a big nuisance -the maze of connected levels through the New York subway- it starts to grow on you, it feels like you are right there with Jackie Estacado, a betrayed hitman for the mafia, helping him travel from the one rotten place to the next forsaken hell (literally) all the while thinking about your sins and the losses you had to suffer. And all of this because a evil force is helping you fulfill your vengeance but by every heart taken from the bodies of fallen enemies it takes you one step closer to the darkness and its goal to ultimately take complete control of your mind, will and body. There develops and plays out a story that’s gruesome and poetic at times, you will remember it, it will haunt you.

Let's spill the beans right now for those not interested in reading a lengthy piece. It's not easy to follow up Starbreeze's gem but Digital Extremes (DE) did a good job for a sequel. While it does not satisfy as much and does not answer all the burning questions you have after playing the first one (how did Jackie return?) they at least took over most important aspects and characters from the first one that made it memorable and continue on those. That also has it's flip side, when a sequel focuses on the most memorable aspects it forgets the subtle details that made the first great. The new york subway as a game hub is no more and therefore the unique pacing of the first game is also gone. This game capitalizes on the action and creates a big deja vu of the first story and works towards a way too obvious end. As such you will feel for the characters only because you went on the dark journey with them in the first, not from what you experience in the Darkness II.

But the action, that it does good. While I personally enjoyed the more realistic style of the first, the cell shaded look of the second game will not throw you off that much. It's still gory and it still has many themes that could be deemed controversial for a game and I guess because the game did not became that much of a hit that these moments have gone unnoticed. The gun game play is improved and you get more darkness powers to play with (damn you stupid skill trees, choices, choices...). DE was also smart enough to leave out some overpowered skills out of the game or downgrade them a little bit to make the playing field more fair. The enemies are also much aware of the Darkness and it's powers and flaws and are much tougher then the unknowing mobsters from the first game. Flash grenades and portable lights will certainly give you a fight to find a spot of darkness and to unleash your dark powers.

In the end I enjoyed the darkness II very much for its game play and rehearses of the first games story. However, I play a game for it's story and hoped for a different direction, a story arc the same as the first is a bit of a let down. If you have your heart set on playing this then play the first game first and then decide if you want to play the Darkness II. If you do you will at least play this game with more passion for the characters and you will already have developed a love/hate relationship with one of the coolest voices featured in a game and the gravely twisted mind that is the Darkness.

reviewText:
Ok, so I was expecting a regular FPS.
But, I was wrong, Darkness II was a bit of a shocker to me, it was really good, kinda short maybe, but fun and had a solid story.

Story: (Trying not to make spoilers)
The game is based on a comic series called, yep, you guessed it, The Darkness.
You play as Jackie Estacado, a mafia boss that possess the forces of darkness.
Jackie tries to keep his darkness at bay, but after a rival mafia tries to kill you, you have no option but to start a war and unleash the darkness within you upon your enemies.
But, when you unleash the darkness, you also cut a deal with it, and there's a price to pay at the end...

Graphics:
The game graphics reminded me Borderlands but more realistic, and i like it :) kinda gives you the feel of a comics (which it is based on a comic series)

Gameplay:
The game is FPS and RPG of some sort, where you gain XP from kills and level your skills, but apart from the guns and black magic you also have 2 tenticals that devours, kill, cutting off heads and ripping the limbs of people (Tons of blood and gore)
When you are not cutting and killing, you also play as your little lackey, which is more stealthy than just killing everybody.
Also, there are some levels that are purely for the story, they are short but very fun and delivers the awesome story to you, I loved those parts!

Conclusion:
This game kinda surprised me, I loved the story, the cut-scenes are great, the gameplay is fun, the graphics are very nice and feel you get is very good.
and even though it's short (took me about 6 hours to finish the game on Hard, but you can play it and make different decisions), it's really good!
Play it!

***There's also multiplayer but I didn't play it honestly, for no reason really***

reviewText:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=z-s94Tex4yg&list=UU7_-PLIhjsEBwIQXqKxmNpA

The Darkness II is a first person shooter with some strong story
elements.  It also offers some multiplayer/co-op options, where you have
the availability to play a different campaign than the one you play solo,
which is nice.

The story is loosely based on The Darkness comic series, and takes
place two years after the first game.  You play as Jackie Estacado, the don
of a crime family that posesses a supernatural power called The Darkness.
With this power, you have extra arms, or tentacles, that can pick up enemies,
throw objects, and  other options that are added as you progress through the
game. The story is very narrational based and entertaining, and connects on
an emotional level to the player.

There are a variety of weapons that are offered;  the recoil on even
the most basic weapons are very well done, as well as the aim and reload time.
They don't ever feel like they are too weak.  The combat is also done well,
giving a sense of urgency as you progress through, and a fluidity during
battles.

The darkness has powers and abilities that you can unlock and upgrade
as you progress through the game.  There is a decent variety in the selection
of abilities, and they do run on a cool down time.  I felt that the combat
was fair, and rewarded me appropriately as I went through levels.

As for level design, the game is very linear, but it does compensate
for that with a strong fluidity of the combat.  As you progress through
the levels, the story as well as the fluidity of combat helps break up the
linear feel of it.  The game is consistant in its' aesthetic and atmosphere,
and everything flowed very well.

There were a few minor issues, which I detail in my video review, but
overall this is a good game with well done combat and a compelling story.  The
level design is basic, but I never felt my time was wasted, and I can easily
recommend this game.

reviewText: One of my favorite comic books, and done pretty pretty damn well, twice, but in completely different flavors.  The first one had more of a roaming kinda feel, go through the city, and all that, this one is more traditional FPS level based like Doom or wolfenstein.  but with plenty of story throughout. Alot more gore than the first one, but the cell shaded comic look to the set is done great. I really love this game. The tone is gritty and dark with a good pallette of colors. The audio is top notch and the music suited the game, but nothing noteworthy that I can remember, haven't bought or dl'd the soundtrack. The ending was abrupt and left me wanting more with no real final boss either.  But good overall, and I would like a continuation. Fans of the series will find this a must buy. 7/10

reviewText:
It's a fun game, for the six or so hours that the campaign lasts. And I played it on hard.

You play as a generic mafioso who, after the tutorial, reveals that he's the host for The Darkness, a malevolent entity which gleefully kills people in a bunch of horrifically fun ways. About halfway through the plot your character is killed and is then resurrected by The Darkness, which makes you realize that dying during gameplay really shouldn't be that big a deal if your inner demon can just bring you back to life following the subtle plot twist of getting shotgunned in the face.

I have some minor gripes with the controls; you'll want to remap them or else your attempts to aim, shoot, and flail around with your demon arms basically results in you stumbling and haphazardly firing your guns into the ceiling and walls like a drunken redneck.

There is a variety of enemies to encounter who make the combat a lot of fun and interesting.

The plot and it's overall theme of sanity and evil versus absolute evil were quite enjoyable, and I liked that the game had at least two different endings.

I haven't played the 'vendetta' content yet, but considering the Main Story" lasted less than six hours I feel justified reviewing the game without playing all of its content."

reviewText:
Fret not if you've never played the original Darkness. While many allusions are made its way, The Darkness II has you covered with a concise recap.

The first Darkness was a mess of a game, marred with terrible voice acting, animations, controls, gameplay, and numerous other bugs. The Darkness II, a product by another team of developers, is fortunately an exemplary sequel, fixing nearly every flaw and adding major improvements in ways unimaginable.

Graphically, The Darkness II's cel shading is simply beautiful, fitting right in with its comic book counterpart. The animations are smooth and the over-the-top violence is a blast to watch. Controls, especially during combat, flow extremely well, even in the face of the overwhelming number abilities available.

While the single player campaign isn't too lengthy, the game doubles its duration with the inclusion of a cooperative mode offering 18 missions and 4 new, unique characters. There's simply a lot of content to be found.

Grade: B

reviewText:
Fantastic game.

The gameplay itself is quite smooth considering you have two pistols or a heavier weapon and two darkness arms to control all at the same time. It allows for violent executions right in the middle of combat as well as throwing objects from the environment at your foes. The single player itself is short however worth a second playthrough to fully upgrade your skills,
and there is also a multiplayer co op mode that lets up to four players work together as characters with special darkness powers and weapons unique to them, and players have the ability to upgrade those characters as well although it isn't as expansive as Jacky, the protagonists, skillset.

The story, while I won't spoil much is really good, however at the same time it is currently the game's biggest weakness, because the game ends in a big cliffhanger and there is no sequel in sight.

reviewText:
This game is unashamedly and appallingly gory, but fun. (Don't know what tht says about me).

I'd never have played it if it hadn't been on offer for a silly price somewhere or another**,  I'd have missed a good game.

The combat is pretty cool, the game has a unique style, and yep, there's even a story.

Boss fights are a little disappointing, and the ending could have been better - but that didn't spoil the fun.
And there's an additional element of Vendettas (single player or co-op) which run alongside the main story - kind of filling in some gaps, where you can play as different characters.

Worth checking out IMHO.

**One of the things I love about PC gaming, as opposed to console, is coming across little nuggets like this for practically no cost - yummy :)

reviewText: With it's story depending highly on your experience of Starbreeze's console exclusive release of 2007, it is some wonder that this sequel to Darkness was made available for PC or, heck, even at all when you consider how the first game even ended. Yet with the stark differences in art-style and ultimately approach to the structure itself  in The Darkness 2, Digital Extremes also wisely fixed the cumbersome combat of the original Darkness with much better shooting mechanics and much better implementation of the titular demon itself during fights. Additionally, the co-op heavy Vendettas game mode is a nice surprise and a lot of fun both online and off. Performance is neither an issue here or there with this one, The Darkness II can be maxed out smoothly on modest DX10 video cards and budget Dual core CPUs although it doesn't quite have proper full-frame support, squashing the picture similar to Digital Extreme's previous work on Homefront. Otherwise, aside from the occassional cheap enemy chokepoint, you're more than likely to enjoy what you get out of The Darkness II, especially if it is less than £5.

reviewText:
One of the better fps games I've ever played. Solid, unflinching combat mechanics, great graphics, cool story, and a lot of fun to play. Not only can you dual wield weapons, you have two demon arms that come out of you to slash and grab enemies and do gruesome executions, and you can grab items and throw them at enemies. The ultra-violence in this game knows no limits. Another big plus: the story is easily one of the best video game stories I've ever seen. Simple to grasp yet very well written and well acted, even sad at times. The graphics are also very well done and hold up well today even as of 2016, with a almost Borderlands-ish comic style. But things look more human-like and the game is much more serious than BL games, and it manages to feel like its own style of art.

If you like well made FPS games that feel nice and tight when you play them, like a young, hot, 18yr old super-long haired red head prom date with a quiver in her panties that you can feel on your leg while dancing, quit waiting and go for it.

reviewText:
In general a very enjoyable game. Not going to lie, it has a few kinks I hope they fix for Darkness III (oh please let it happen), but those are easy to look past considering all the other great parts of the game.

Good things:
The story about Jenny is fantastic (minor spoiler, yes she's in the game a bit). It really got me sucked into it all because alot of very logical things surfaced when playing, which gave a rather interresting perspective about the game itself.
The gore...I mean come on you have to love it. Actually one of the most brutal games I've ever played, but at the same time not the most graphic one. The artstyle makes you enjoy it alot more than get grossed out by it.
The artstyle I can't explain why but I really like it. It has a comic noir sense to it and looks really good.
The gameplay has a really nice touch to it. Demons and guns, how do you say no to that? Also there's a skilltree you level up depending on how you want to play, so personalized customization for you and your abilities.
Finally you can tell that the developers have put alot of time and effort into the game because of all the amazing voiceacting. If you feel like it you can double your gameplay time by talking to everyone possible and not only get alot of info about what's going on and personal opinions which add alot of depth to the story, you can also enjoy a comedic side to this game which I personally was happily surprised to discover.

Things that can be improved:
First thing that comes to mind is the amount of execution animations. Though horrendous and incredible great to watch, they get quite repetitive once you've played for a while. For the next game I wish they mix it up a bit and expand the ways you can kill people with your demons, because, and be honest to yourself, that is one of the coolest things about this game.
Secondly I really enjoyed the story and the campaign and it all had a nice flow all the way through. I just wish for the flow to extend another few hours. I finished the game in about ten hours or so, and I really think a game should be longer than that. Especially since this one doesn't have free roaming and maybe not so much replay value since the story is such a big part of the game.

Overall I give this game 8.5/10. Get it and enjoy this very unique FPS where YOU are the nightmare everyone fears ;)

reviewText: Darkness II is one of these games that have many advantages as a game but many drawbacks , too.The graphcis are unusually good (cell-shaded), but the music-soundtrack is uninteresting.The single player is awsome , interesting story , good and solid FPS mechanics , and a awesome skilltree(which give you the ability to unlock both passives and active skills and ofcourse improvments to them).After finishing the single player campaign you can start again a NG++ which means you will keep the unlocked skills you already have from the previous campaign , I personally found it pretty awesome and I had a totally different experience from the 1st playthrough.Except from the campaign single player, the game also gives you the opportunity to play some side missions (which are called vendettas), with 4 new characters each one with his own skilltree and abilities , and a  extra small campaignin which is basically the sum up of the vendettas (or the opposite) .Furthemore some vendettas can be completed with multiplayer co-op. The major drawback is that the main campaign will only last for 5 hours tops (it took me 8 hours with a NG++ game) ,and the vendettas will give you 2-3 more hours.If you decide ofcourse to play the extra campaign or the vendettas with all the charactes (I doubt you will :P ), the time will be multiplied.So here comes the critical question : Are you able/willing to give 30 $ for a game it will only last 12-14 hours tops?Yes the story will be great and Yes the powers and abilities of darkness will be unforgetable but will it worth for the so little time it will last....?In my opinion NO ...buy this game like a did at a steam sale (80%=5$) and you will not regret it.

reviewText:
NOTE: Despite my short playing time, I have in fact completed this game. I also own a copy on Xbox 360, and this is the copy I completed.

The Darkness II is a phsycological horror first-person shooter sequel to The Darkness, a console only game released back in 2009. The original game was interesting despite its flaws, and was a highly enjoyable game in terms of story and gameplay. Its sequel, The Darkness II, goes above and beyond to deliver an absolute gem of a gaming experience, and a masterpiece of the art form.
You play as Jackie Estacado, the head of a feared crime family, who is the host to an ancient evil known as The Darkness - this evil resides inside Jackie and gives him supernatural powers. Jackie constantly wrestles for control, and The Darkness forced him to stand by and watch as his girlfriend, Jenny, was murdered.
Jenny's murder is the driving force of this entire game. Throughout the game, Jackie experiences hallucinations of Jenny, and interacts with her as she if she never died. These moments are the soul of the game; Jackie and Jenny are beautifully acted, and you can genuinely feel the emotion in these scenes. This made the story a compelling and enjoyable one, and I felt personally compellled to stick this game through to the end.
In between cutscenes and interaction with Jenny and other NPC's, Jackie will engage in numerous combat situations. This game uses a unique and innovative combat system, in that the player is able to 'quad-wield'; the player is able to dual wield one handed firearms in combination with the demon tendrils produced by The Darkness. These tendrils let you rip, slash, throw, tear and stab your enemies in a variety of highly entertaining ways, but be warned that these kills are extremely gory and not for the faint hearted. In fact, the entire game is extremely dark, and contains very dark subject matter beyond the usual video game. The player also has to avoid street lights and other artificial lights and shoot them out where possible, as you cannot regenerate health or use Darkness abilities whilst in the light.
This game is beautiful in every aspect. The game engine employs a distinct comic-book inspired aesthetic like the Borderlands games, and it really helps make the game look and run nice at the higher settings. Substantial effort and polish has gone into the production of this game, and it really shows; character models look and move realistically, and environments are dazzling to look at.
In addition to the perfected single player campaign (which I have been careful not to spoil) there is a mini co-op campaign, which allows you to play with 3 friends and use a wide range of guns and abilities to kill enemies. This mode emphasises fun and action, and lacks the depth of the single player campaign. However, it was certainly fun, and I didn't feel like it detracted from the campaign in any way.
Overall, The Darkness II is a masterpiece of the gaming industry. A brilliant, well constructed tale of love and loss and eventually redemption, this is a game for the ages. I can't recommend it any more than I already have, which is why this game earns a 10 / 10.

reviewText:
While loving the first, The Darkness 2 felt like a disappointment.

You are two years later, and are still very much feeling the aftermath. You're a Don now, leading a crime organisation that seems to feel smaller than implied.

You go to a restaurant and get attacked by a bunch of janitors. Almost intently, they force you to survive by releasing the Darkness, which Jackie had locked up ever since last time.

What follows is a path of revenge. First to retalliate, then avenge your Aunt, then recover a plot-vital artifact... you're basically on a railroad of motivations, which feels artificial.
No surprise that the story really isn't engaging.

But the surrounding side characters are a redeeming factor. NPC's are often in pairs and have some funny banter. And spamming talk to hear them out leads into a long strain of comments about their own backstory. They may be somewhat shallow characters, but there's a sense of personality to them.

In particular, the Darkling seems to be filled with it. He slowly starts to play a big part in the story, and is generally a hoot to listen to. A major improvenemt over the first game.

Gameplay wise, what's changed isn't per se for the better.
You still have your whip, but it feels much shorter and riskier to use to whip out lights. It relies on your input to see what direction to swipe, which feels counter-intuitive.

You can grab a car door or anything shield-like to carry in front of you as protection while you shoot. A great idea at first, but impractical over time, as eating hearts removes the shield and you can't use the whip. Not to mention that the smallest light drops it.
Not much of a problem at first, until you start encountering the Brotherhood...

Corpses still carry hearts to consume, but living ones serve a different purpose now as well.
Instead of four awesome Darkness powers, your powers now largely revolve around stunning an enemy, then grasping him.
Upon which you can then decide what to do with them.
Mainly, they can serve as a quick health refill, an ammo refill (yep), a shield creator or a cooldown reducer.

You also have two active cooldown-based abilities.
One is swarm, which briefly blind/stuns your enemy, making them vulnerable.
The other briefly infuses your guns with the Darkness, giving you infinite ammo and raised damage. But it's not really a lifesaver.

All of this fancy stuff however has to be unlocked first, using points you earn in combat. The fancier the kill, the more points you get.
In general, the upgrades are okay. They're nothing spectacular. Although the Darkness armor does look mighty nice. It seems based upon the armor from the comics.

In the end, I felt like the Darkness was more of a crutch that slowed me down. I was constantly juggling with my Gunplay and my Darkness powers, annoyingly so.

The Brotherhood, which past halfway will be your mainstay enemies, often carry light-beams, which will just annoy the hell out of you. Whenever you are in light now, your screen goes black and white and drop any non-weapon you are holding (such as shields). It's quite disruptive.

Not to mention the Whip guys.... These guys will snatch whatever weapon you are holding.
Or the shielders who knock you around, while requiring either swarm or multiple whip slashing to be knocked away.
Or the Heavy guys that, for some reason, blink around the place whenever they are hurt.
These guys get my vote as most-annoying ever.
Thankfully you're done with the story in about eight hours.

Vendettas seems to largely be a redeeming feature.
You can pick one of four that each have one Darkness ability.
This is a good thing, as the focus seems to be much more on the gunplay. You still get the annoying light effect, but you feel much less disabled.
Quite frankly, I feel like I'm having a much better time in Vendettas.

The Darkness 2 is like a bad sequel to a good movie. You cringe, but you can still see what you liked about the original.

Get it while it's on sale, play the Single Player on Easy and try and make the best out of it...

reviewText:
A surprising gem. Gunplay is solid, if a little uninspired. Story was gripping throughout and very well paced: people have complained about the length, but I felt I got more than my money's worth. This game is lovely to look at, and despite its age, still holds a candle to any modern shooter thanks to its expertly rendered cell-shading, which maintains a perfect comic book vibe throughout, and allows the graphics to remain essentially timeless.

Two places the game falls down, to differing extent are the atmosphere and level design.

Atmosphere is largely absent from this game unfortunately, despite offering a mythos that could easily be exploited for spine-tingling vibes. The soundtrack is completely forgettable and generic, and the ambient sound design extremely lacking. While we're on the topic of the mythos, I found myself not caring much. The game makes many attempts to engage you with the mythos, but such attempts felt only about three-quarter-♥♥♥♥♥. Perhaps this is a problem with the source material, I'm unsure. I normally dive into mythos pretty heavily, but despite my best efforts, I couldn't engage with this game's beyond the initial veneer. Something was lacking.

As to level design, while I wouldn't say it was atrocious, or even bad, it was thoroughly uninspired. One often has the sensation of moving from room to room, both figuratively and literally. Not only is the design linear, but it offers little opportunity to exploit level features to one's advantage. With that said, many of the sets look goregous, although just as many are enither here nor there.

I've begun rambling here, so I'll just say, if you can get this game for $5 you'll have gotten more than your money's worth, and I'd even happily drop a tenner on it. At the time of this review, full price is $40, and there's simply no way this game is worth that when one considers what else is available for that kind of price, however it regularly goes on sale for large discounts. I regularly see it at ~80% off, so if you can get it at that kind of discount (and you can if you're patient) I recommend it.

Game ends on a cliffhanger and no sequel announced thus far, so keep that in mind. However that this bothered me at all speaks to how much I ended up enjoying the story of this game. I give it 3/5 stars.

reviewText: The Darkness 2 is what I like to classify as a power-fantasy game. You will often find yourself wading into enemies, shooting and tearing your enemies to pieces all around you. Health and cover are not a huge issue as you can tear the hearts out of fallen/staggered foes for a health boost on the fly.\n\nThe game also boasts what they call quad-wielding"; allowing you to use your demon tendrils as an extra 2 hands. This lets you actively grab items and enemies
date: hold shields or use the tendrils as a close range whip; all while keeping your actual hands free to fire your guns. The combat is fast and furious and feels very satisfying.\n\nAn interesting mechanic is the fact that your Darkness powers don't work in the light
recommended: and your enemies in the mid-late parts of the game know this. Enemies will come at you with shoulder mounted spotlights and employ flashbangs to try and slow you down. It keeps it interesting as the enemy with the light instantly becomes your priority regardless of the armored shotgunners 10 feet away from you.\n\nThe story is engaging and fun
hoursPlayed: but is not too long. You play the head of a mafia family with powers known as "The Darkness" as your organization engages in all out war with an ancient dark cult intent on stealing your powers and killing anyone in their way. Definitely not a plot you come across often! Overall

reviewText: The Darkness released early February 2012 and was a game that didn’t receive much advertising or player generated hype. The Darkness 2 follows the story Jackie Estacado a mob boss who inherits a peculiar ability which is wielding the Darkness. The game uses cell shading similar to borderlands which compliments the game world well. The gameplay is quite original and lets you “quad-wield” which basically means you can wield a gun in each hand while also controlling your two darkness demon arms. The controls feel a bit fiddly when using a mouse and keyboard, if you own a controller I would recommend using that instead. This game has some of the most gruesome kills I have ever seen in a game. Using your demonic arms you can rip your enemies in half, slice of their head or even pull out an enemy’s spine from his butt the list goes on. The single player campaign took me about 6 hours on my first play through and left me wanting more, not because the game was bad but because it was so darn good. There is also a co-op campaign which was fun to play with friends but got boring very quickly. In summary, I really enjoyed this game and its unique gameplay but found it was bit to short.

reviewText: The Darkness 2 is what I like to classify as a power-fantasy game. You will often find yourself wading into enemies, shooting and tearing your enemies to pieces all around you. Health and cover are not a huge issue as you can tear the hearts out of fallen/staggered foes for a health boost on the fly.\n\nThe game also boasts what they call quad-wielding"; allowing you to use your demon tendrils as an extra 2 hands. This lets you actively grab items and enemies
date: hold shields or use the tendrils as a close range whip; all while keeping your actual hands free to fire your guns. The combat is fast and furious and feels very satisfying.\n\nAn interesting mechanic is the fact that your Darkness powers don't work in the light
recommended: and your enemies in the mid-late parts of the game know this. Enemies will come at you with shoulder mounted spotlights and employ flashbangs to try and slow you down. It keeps it interesting as the enemy with the light instantly becomes your priority regardless of the armored shotgunners 10 feet away from you.\n\nThe story is engaging and fun
hoursPlayed: but is not too long. You play the head of a mafia family with powers known as "The Darkness" as your organization engages in all out war with an ancient dark cult intent on stealing your powers and killing anyone in their way. Definitely not a plot you come across often! Overall

reviewText:
I never finished the first Darkness because it wasn't on PC and I suck at shooters on my PS3. So fortunately there was a previously on Darkness at the start of this game, but to be honest it wasn't very detailed so I had to go to wikipedia to find out what happened in the first Darkness.

Regardless of that, it doesn't take you long to be pulled into the story. The Darkness 2 does a great job of immersing you into the feelings and thoughts of the main character, which is a rarity in modern day gaming. Often you are very disconected from the story and the emotions of the characters. Lately, the only other game I have played that did such a great job of pulling you in, emotionally, was BioShock Infinite.

Beyond the story, which while nothing especially impressive (mostly due to the fact the game is only 6 hours long), what is there is enough and is well orcestrated. The most impressive feat is the game's ability to put you in the shoes of the main character and really doubt what is real and what is not real (in the game).

The gameplay is top notch though and if you enjoy shooters where you run from one area to the next and have to clear all the waves of enemies, then this is a game for you. The gunplay is fun and has impact and the tentacles are well implemented so that they are not overpowered and yet are still very fun and exciting to use. I found myself using primarily guns but definitely had to use my powers frequently to stay in the fight. I was glad though that the powers did not dominate the gameplay so that you simply use the powers when you feel the need and are not forced to constantly use the powers. In some games where you have powers they dominate the other gameplay mechanics to the point that you find yourself only using the powers and nothing else. Fortunately, this is not the case in the Darkness 2.

The graphics are not impressive or special, but they make up for what they lack in the style, which once you've played the game to completion the style will make sense. A lot of people were surprised when they first revealed the first gameplay video of The Darkness 2 because of the art style they had used. But there is a definite reason for it and it only further helps immerse you into the world of confusion that the main character is living in.

The soundtrack is great and the voice work is top quality. All in all, it is a very fun game with a decent story that manages to pull you in and leaves you desiring more.

Would definitely recommend giving this game a spin! It is a great purchase and a great experience to play through once or even twice! In addition there are even some co-op missions to further the experience, so if you have a friend to play it with it will add a few more hours of quality gameplay.

reviewText:
This is a game that took me by surprise. After hearing average reviews of this game, I went to it expecting the average, run of the mill FPS that we've recently become accustomed to. Not only was it above average and exceeded what I was expecting, it killed it. Almost everything in this game was done well, and even some of the stuff that missed still wasn't that bad.

Plot: The Darkness 2 is about Jackie Estacado, the protagonist from the first game that you may remember, if you played it. That being said though, you don't have to have played the first one to understand the story of this one. It's been a few years since the events of the first game, and the death of Jenny. Jackie's been keeping the darkness under control, but after a hit is put out on him, he can't control it anymore. You'll learn about ancient artifacts, a secret society, and two different endings, which offers a bit of replay value.

Setting: This game has many different set pieces, and while the first hour or so is repetitive in terms of the stages, the rest of the game has much more creative level design. Even in the hallucinations he has, the asylum is one of the most interesting and also tense settings I've ever seen, providing a frightening reality of being trapped and unable to escape. If you choose the ending to fight the darkness and save Jenny, you'll have to fight in Hell, which is in my opinion, one of the most beautiful levels I've seen in a game, ever.


Gameplay: On its surface, The Darkness 2 may seem like a bog standard shooter, and at some points, it is. But Jackie gets all sorts of awesome and violent powers to wield. With many skills you can level up using essence" (a sort of xp you get for doing various things
