reviewText:
Aren't these the guys who developed Unreal and Unreal Tournament? I know of no other Digital Extremes. Beside them you also have 2K so you really have everything you need to make a really good game.

I never played the first one as it was never released on PC. But from what I understand the story takes place a couple of years after the events of its predecessor. You play the don of an infamous crime family who is attacked at the beginning of the story. One of the rival gangs almost eliminates Jackie, our protagonist, who eventually gives in to the Darkness which saves his life.

And this is where the game gets interesting: Jackie has two tentacles protruding from his body and you can use them to crush, dismember or simply slice up your enemies. Oh, and of course you have your good old pistols, machine guns and shotguns to annihilate all the bad guys approaching you. Jackie did not want the Darkness to return - under the circumstances, however, he needs to rely on them and throughout the game you need to find out who and why attacked you in the restaurant.

With the tentacles you can also pick up objects - e.g. the door of a vehicle - and throw them at your enemies. And as you can do some dual wielding with the firearms you can practically say you are doing quad wielding with the two tendrils. How cooler can a game be, am I right? With the killings you can collect what the game calls essence; a substance that eventually lets you purchase new powers or the upgraded version of the ones you already have. It should also be note that as the title refers to it darkness is also Jackie's ally - if you are in an illuminated area the tentacles immediately retract.

Darkness II is a fast-paced action horror game that utilises a cel-shading technique to give the game a comic book influenced visual style. Multiplayer is limited to cooperative gameplay that does not really add anything to the story but lets you enjoy quad wielding with your friends.

I highly recommend it - for 30 EUR it's a bit too much at the moment but you should definitely pick this one up if discounted.

reviewText: I feel the Darkness!  Want the Darkness!  Honestly, it's a very good cell shaded type game.  It takes what looks like an old page out of a comic book and implements it into a cell shaded world.  Honestly the game does it well.  The levels have a pretty even split and playing as the Darkness is just plain fun.  Eating human hearts, decapitation, splitting the soul, and testing out an Iron Maiden.  Honestly, the game has only a couple of little flaws.  The story line is, ok.  It lacks a really epic story line, and it gets old somewhere in the middle and picks up again towards the end.  Gameplay is very good and the game requires you to learn to implement and even combination of darkness powers and gun totting.  If it's on sale I definitely recommend picking up a copy.  The game is good, and there aren't too many prevalent flaws.  Installation of the game went without a hitch.

reviewText:
I was skeptical of this game upon hearing of cel-shading & the change in dev teams, but gosh gee, if it were only longer I'd put it on par with the cult classic first title. The story pulls you in just the same with its subtle lore hidden thruout, but I would say the pacing is really skittish in the first half of the game. The Darkness' powers are as fun as ever to use for tearing apart dumb New York mobsters & cultists, & the voice-acting, especially from Johnny & Jackie, is top-notch work--coupled with the detailed characterization made possible w/ the comic-book graphics that give so much life to the cast.

The game takes 'bout 7 hours to complete on SP if you take your time, & the MP campaign brings an additional 2 hours minimum (it has some replayability--but it def lacks the polish and attention-to-detail of the SP half, just being a series of strewn-together 4-player shootfests with a touch of the Darkness' power).

Here's hoping we'll see more of the Darkness.

And this is where the game gets interesting: Jackie has two tentacles protruding from his body and you can use them to crush, dismember or simply slice up your enemies. Oh, and of course you have your good old pistols, machine guns and shotguns to annihilate all the bad guys approaching you. Jackie did not want the Darkness to return - under the circumstances, however, he needs to rely on them and throughout the game you need to find out who and why attacked you in the restaurant.

With the tentacles you can also pick up objects - e.g. the door of a vehicle - and throw them at your enemies. And as you can do some dual wielding with the firearms you can practically say you are doing quad wielding with the two tendrils. How cooler can a game be, am I right? With the killings you can collect what the game calls essence; a substance that eventually lets you purchase new powers or the upgraded version of the ones you already have. It should also be note that as the title refers to it darkness is also Jackie's ally - if you are in an illuminated area the tentacles immediately retract.

Darkness II is a fast-paced action horror game that utilises a cel-shading technique to give the game a comic book influenced visual style. Multiplayer is limited to cooperative gameplay that does not really add anything to the story but lets you enjoy quad wielding with your friends.

I highly recommend it - for 30 EUR it's a bit too much at the moment but you should definitely pick this one up if discounted.

reviewText:
Well, this was an interesting game to play. A fresh air after playing so many crappy indie productions.

Pros:
- the plot is kind of nice if you know something about Image Comics and the Artifacts series - reading the story of hidden relics and immersing in the whole Darkness backstory is really fun
- graphics are well fitting into comic book stylistics
- playing with the Darkness tentacles is really fun
- the whole concept of destroying light sources in order to be able to use the Darkness is an interesting idea, well fitting into the whole concept of the Darkness
- character development system is not overwhelming the whole game - there is no point in maxing out character except for pure fun
- some abilities give a lot of tactical advantages and possibilities - black holes can be of great help and autoaiming provided by one of high tier abilities, even while lasting about 5 seconds, can make the difference
- last levels in hell are very nice and atmospheric

Cons:
- the plot is kind of dumb if you're not into The Darkness comic books - Darkness says something, blablabla, Angelus blablabla, Brotherhood blablabla, vengance yadayada, Jenny hurrdurr, so on and so forth
- you cannot skip some cutscenes - this is really bad
- well, considering this is a shooter there aren't many different weapons - pistol, revolver, desert eagle, two different shotguns, winchester (you have it for about 15 minutes), two or three smgs, two or three different assault rifles and that's all
- guns can use ammo really fast and there are not really that many ammo boxes laying around so you can find yourself in a situation where you don't have any bullets to shoot
- I think that the games relies too much on the finisher mechanics - need to replenish health? Use Finisher #1. Need to get some additional ammo - guessed it, Finisher #2. Considering that uzis and other guns do use ammo pretty fast you may find yourself in a situation that you try to finish enemies with Finisher #1 or #2
- special abilities are fun to use, but recharge slow and you don't really need them - they help, true, but they are not game changing abilities like for example slow motion in Max Payne 1.
- this game is short (about 6-7 hours)

As you can see I have described many cons so you may think that this is a mediocre game. By any means no, this is a really good game, I had a lot of fun playing it. There is New Game + option after beating the game, which adds some playtime if someone would like to go for the second run and max out character abilities. In the first run I think you can get 60-70% of all abilities so there is just enough reason to play the game for the second time.

I just pass this option because I don't like to watch the same long cutscenes over again.

Anyways... you can try Demo. Go and try it.

reviewText:
This is a game that took me by surprise. After hearing average reviews of this game, I went to it expecting the average, run of the mill FPS that we've recently become accustomed to. Not only was it above average and exceeded what I was expecting, it killed it. Almost everything in this game was done well, and even some of the stuff that missed still wasn't that bad.

Plot: The Darkness 2 is about Jackie Estacado, the protagonist from the first game that you may remember, if you played it. That being said though, you don't have to have played the first one to understand the story of this one. It's been a few years since the events of the first game, and the death of Jenny. Jackie's been keeping the darkness under control, but after a hit is put out on him, he can't control it anymore. You'll learn about ancient artifacts, a secret society, and two different endings, which offers a bit of replay value.

Setting: This game has many different set pieces, and while the first hour or so is repetitive in terms of the stages, the rest of the game has much more creative level design. Even in the hallucinations he has, the asylum is one of the most interesting and also tense settings I've ever seen, providing a frightening reality of being trapped and unable to escape. If you choose the ending to fight the darkness and save Jenny, you'll have to fight in Hell, which is in my opinion, one of the most beautiful levels I've seen in a game, ever.

reviewText:
Download size: Less than 10 gb
Play time: About 6 hours for campaign

The Darkness 2 is based on a popular comic book that I haven’t read, and the first Darkness game never made it to Steam/PC. Fortunately, I found the story strong enough to stand alone so I didn’t feel like I was missing any important backstory. There’s a “previously on the Darkness” cutscene that you can watch upon starting a new game, and there’s actually some “talking head” scenes between game chapters where the protagonist Jackie talks to the player as if he’s narrating his autobiography, so you should be caught up pretty quick.

You play Jackie Estacado, a kind of Mafia boss who has sworn off using the Darkness, a demonic entity that inhabits his body and gives him superhuman powers at the cost of his soul. Too bad for Jackie, a powerful mysterious group comes to town determined to reclaim the Darkness, which they used to be caretakers for. Since the Darkness can only be given up willingly, the only way for them to get it back is by turning Jackie’s life upside down and torturing him into giving it up. This means war.

The Darkness 2 is a first person shooter with the gimmick of having 2 Darkness tentacles that you can use to grab objects or slash at enemies with. You can also dual wield many one handed guns, so essentially you have 4 limbs to kill people with (2 guns + 2 tentacles). The Darkness also gives you a few powers that you unlock through purchasing in darkness “shrines” found throughout the world. You get dark essence by killing enemies and finding special artifacts, then spend the essence at the shrines on skills and upgrades. It’s not an open world game, you just find the shrines all over the place along the way. There are 4 skill trees to spend your essence in, but you won’t find enough essence in one playthrough to purchase everything. You’ll need to use the New Game + option and grind for more essence.

One of the key game elements is the need to destroy light sources (lamps, street lights, etc.) since bright lights will inhibit the Darkness, causing your screen to lens flare out and go black and white. Your powers and Darkness tentacles are also disabled when this happens so if you’re playing one of the higher difficulty levels you need to snipe out lights before you get too close. The Darkness 2 uses a regenerating health system like Gears of War or any of the Modern Warfare games so if you’re taking too much damage, get behind something for a few seconds to recover.

Pros:
+Excellent story with some twisted enemy bosses. The boss battles aren’t spectacular, but you’ll probably really hate those dudes by the time you get to fight them.
+Pretty good graphics, which kind of remind me of the Borderlands games but with more detail. There are a number of death animations for various ways that you can use the Darkness to execute weakened enemies. The tentacle arm executions can be gruesome.
+The game has a long co-op campaign called Vendettas, though I have only tried a few of the missions (they run parallel to the single player campaign with 4 new characters). The Vendetta missions have their own bosses and you can build up character specific skill trees with dark essence gathered in multiplayer games.

Cons:
-There are a ton of characters and even though I’ve played through the game twice, I only know the names of 3-4 of them. I’m sure most of them were in the first game so they’re just making appearances in part 2. They aren’t all that important though, so no sweat.
-The game is very short at under 6 hours for your first playthrough, but this doesn’t include the Vendetta campaign. It means you probably need a co-op partner to get the full experience. For your second/third playthrough (with all your maxed out powers) if you skip the cutscenes you can probably finish the single player campaign in less than 5 hours.

All in all, the Darkness 2 is a great game and well worth the low price you can find it at. It was even in the $1 tier of a Humble Bundle a few months back so you can probably get it cheap. The game’s highlight is the single player story, and you probably won’t find many people playing multiplayer nowadays.

reviewText:
The Darkness II is a pretty solid FPS.

If you know anything about the first game, you know that the first one isn't on PC. Well, two years after the events of the first game, two years after Jackie Estacado takes revenge on Paulie Franchetti for killing his gf, Jenny, and attempting to assasinate him, Jackie is the mob boss of the Franchettie family. In the beginning of the game, the Darkness is dormant within Jackie, the Darkness being a supernatural extension that has transferred itself on the Estacado family line. The story of The Darkness II follows Jackie surviving an assassination attempt in which he awakens the Darkness and hunts down those who attacked him. Unbeknownst to him, someone had set out to kill him or take him alive in order to obtain thd Darkness for themselves. Basically, Jackie uses his resources and his mafia friends to hunt down this group of people, not going to go into to much detail, crazy spoilers on that.

The plot was pretty good, but a bit repetitive. There wasn't too much of a story arc, as it really is rather straightforward; that is until you start to hallucinate yourself in an asylum and much later in the game, hell. Stuff does get bizarre, such as Jackie hallucinating Jenny while in the middle of missions. Even though the Darkness is making him go mad and wants to believe she's real, he understands that he's not exactly in control of his powers.

Well, anyway, the story was good, but it had it's flaws. Onto the technical side of things, like gameplay. Rather simple as far as shooting goes, you've all probably played FPS games so I'm not gonna bother getting into detail. I do want to talk about the tentacles that extend from Jackie's body. They're awesome. I mean, they're evil, but they're great as weapons. You can slice people apart, hold them in the air and flay them, eat their hearts for health (which by the way does mean there's a health bar), you can also control how you slice based on what direction you swing the right stick in, or if you're using a kb/m, it would be the mouse. Graphics were interesting, they using cel shaders for this one to get that comic book style as the game is based on a series of comics, while the first game went for a more realistic look. There are, at points, where the stuttering was bad, mainly in Jackie's penthouse. Otherwise, the framerates were good. A few other bugs here and there, but not enough to say the game is buggy.

Anyway.

8.3/10

Oh, and stay for the post credits scene.

reviewText: The first Darkness is one of my favourite games of all time. When it got terrible reviews I was very upset because I figured that all hope of a sequel was lost. Then the darkness II was announced and my faith in humanity was restored, but there was a problem. The voice of Jackie was replaced, the graphics received that comic book style, and I got really sick of all the jokes and puns in the beginning. As I progressed through the game however, the voice actor for Jackie grew on me, the jokes stopped, the story got incredible and I started really enjoying a more action focused Darkness. It's tough for me to say this, but by the end of the game, The Darkness II is better than its predecessor. It is fantastic. However, I highly recommend playing The Darkness I to truly care about the story and characters, it still remains as one of my favourite games of all time. Sadly though it cannot be found on Steam.

reviewText:
The Darkness II is a surprisingly good first-person shooter albeit a bit too basic for my tastes. It's a very linear game with the same old experience points and upgrade system which seems to be how most first-person shooters are doing it nowadays, but at least there are a couple of interesting ideas to save it from monotony.

The Darkness is based on the comics of the same name. I've unfortunately never read them so I'm not informed enough to make comparisons between it and the video game adaption. I also can't point out any improvements it has made over its predecessor as I don't have any experience with the first game. I'll be treating The Darkness II as its own entity.

So it's lucky that beginners are offered an optional recap of the first game. No need to play catch-up, to play the game. The Darkness II stars an Italian-American don of the Franchetti crime family, Jackie Estacado. Good ole' Jackie has had some problems ever since his girlfriend, Jenny Romano, died in the last game. On top of that, he wields the Darkness, an entity with a mind of its own that has given him supernatural powers. So everything seems to be going well as he has finally gotten the Darkness under control, but then a secret society randomly shows up to try and take this power away from him. As luck would have it, it turns out Jenny is alive somehow and you'll need The Darkness to save her. AND If that wasn't enough, the main character also suffers from hallucinations which may or may not be real meaning that Jackie was a mental patient this whole time and that all of the first game and some sequences in the second game never even happened to begin with.

So it's basically your average comic book plot. It's only a bit disjointed as there are certain elements in the story that really don't go anywhere. Like the fact that you're the head of a crime family, but don't do any mafia-related activities and the gang doesn't really seem to be very helpful except for telling you where to go next. Or the fact that you keep having these visions when time is of the utmost importance and really shouldn't be wasted staring at a wall like say during a chase. There are lot of little things like that, but to its credit the game does wrap up very neatly with every loose end connected.... Well mostly...
I only have two major gripes with the story. One is that the villain is weak. A secret society doesn't sound very interesting to begin with, but their leader fails to impress. You'd think looking like Quasimodo's deformed even uglier cousin would at least make for an intriguing backstory or a good motive, but very little comes of it. Even though he's portrayed as the main villain, he also comes off more as an inconvenience than anything else because his timing really couldn't be worse when it comes to deciding when to steal the Darkness. Secondly, It ends on a cliffhanger and we still haven't seen or heard anything of The Darkness III. The Darkness II came out in 2012 so you can imagine how infuriating it was to see the very last cutscene in the game knowing that they still haven't followed up on it. Sure, there are still the comics, but I don't have easy access to these because I'm a European. Game developers, can you please not end your games like this unless a sequel is guaranteed. Signed, me.

I probably wouldn't have cared a lot about the story if it weren't for the characters. Some of them are very played out with its stereotypical mob characters with the same Italian accents you swear you've heard in ten other games, but it's surprisingly well-acted. Jackie sounds great and you really get the feeling that he really cares about Jennie. In fact, a lot of the characters just sound very human, very convincing if you will. There's a lot of quiet time where characters can develop and reflect on certain events making even the basic grunts a lot more three-dimensional characters than what you would see in most games.

So like I said the before the game is very basic. You get a very limited amount of guns that you could count on one hand and you've got the standard upgrade system in which you spend your experience points. You can sadly only hold three guns at the time. Two one handed guns you can dual-wield and one two-handed gun like a shotgun or a machine gun. What distinguishes The Darkness II from other first-person shooter is obviously the Darkness itself. For one thing, you control an (adorable?), little, British imp called the Darkling. He's practically invincible, able to revive himself an infinite amount of time and will aid you in battle by distracting mooks by hitting them in their stupid faces and then proceeding to urinate on their burning corpses. With later upgrades, you can even throw him at your enemies and causing him to self-destruct after launch. You also have access to two giant tentactles with mouths that come out of your back. These have a lot of useful abilities making the game a bit more interesting. You can swipe them at your enemies, you can grab certain objects and throw them or use them as your shield or you can perform unique execution animations to gain ammo, health, a shield and meter for a special moves (like fusing your gun with Darkness). These animations can sometimes be annoying because they can be very long and occur in quick successions as you'll need all the health and ammo you can get especially in harder difficulties. This can potentially drag out the game.

There's also an interesting dynamic going on related to the light. You see, the Darkness is weak against it. If you find yourself subjected to something that can even be vaguely construed as a light source (like say a street light, a cars headlight, Agent 47's bald head or anything that J.J. Abrahams can somehow turn into a lens flare) then you'll be weakened by it. The tentacles and Darkling will disappear, you can't regenerate health and you can even be blinded by it. In the first part of the game, it comes down to mostly being affected by lightbulbs, but later on enemies will actually use the light against you by either carrying gigantic flash lights or just using traps involving the light. I'm also not sure if this was intentional, but sometimes enemies holding light sources will hide behind enemies with shields making them very hard to fight against as you'll need the Darkness to remove said shield. It's a very interesting mechanic to see and I hope it gets fleshed out in further... oh....

My only real complaint with the game is that it's too easy. I recommend going after the hard difficulty as normal makes the game a bit too boring. I also recommend eventually transitioning to the hardest difficulty Don". I managed to beat Don in my first playthrough

reviewText:
This is what I call a great FPS.
You don't need to have read the comic books to understand this story of revenge and lost love. While it is short (5 hours on the Hard setting), it is really interesting and entertaining thanks to great characters and voice acting.
The gameplay is where the game truly shines: shooting baddies with a Desert Eagle in a hand and a Ump in the other while throwing a spear with a demonic arm and slashing in half a guy with the other arm is really something marvelous. There is plenty of gore, with some really gruesome executions.
The music is okay, neither bad nor memorable.
Overall, it's one of my favourite FPS thanks to great gameplay and story. Plus, you can play 6 missions coop with three other friends.

SCORE: 90/100

P.S. Feel free to add me if you want to do the coop campaign

reviewText:
Have you ever wondered what it would be like to be the head of a major crime syndicate whilst simultaneously being possessed by a creature of pure evil? Well then this might be the game for you.

This is an awesome first person shooter. The gameplay is top-notch, responsive and heart pounding. Each of the guns that you can acquire really packs a punch and you get to see the joy on your enemies faces as you literally blow them away with furious anger and harsh language.

Of course the huge arsenal is not the main attraction of this game. That comes in the form of your two tentacle friends and the terrible powers they grant you. First off the tentacles themselves really pack a punch allowing you to execute some very gruesome and disgusting executions; I think there are at least ten, all of which look really cool… If you happen to be a sadist, which we all are. Then there are the powers, eating hearts to gain health, rapid fire explosive bullets and lobbing black holes just to name a few. You will have a ton of fun tearing your way through the city.

The creators were going for an art style that was reminiscent of a graphic novel and they really hit the nail on the head. The game is beautiful in its own dark way. The environments were nothing too special but each one had its own feel and lent to the overall bleak atmosphere. As for the story, it was pretty good, nothing too amazing but it allowed the player to exact bloody vengeance and tug at the heart strings as well.

Besides the main single player campaign, which only lasts a few hours, there is also a second game mode that can be undertaken in single or multiplayer. In it you get to play as one of four new characters all with their own dark weapons and powers. It added a lot more longevity to the title and with the unique storyline it is well worth a play. I had a go with all the characters to see which one suited me best before blasting my way through everyone who looked at me funny.

This game is awesome and frankly it is very underrated. If you pick this up you will find a very enjoyable and bombastic adventure that will have you want to play through a couple times. Even at full price it’s a good title but on sale you would be mad not to pick it up.

Have fun  ^_^

reviewText:
The Darkness 2 is a game that tries to break from the conventional game molds and provide you with something completely unique. The result is a masterpiece, placing it as the best game of 2012 for me.

You control Jackie Estacado, a mafia lord who has the power of Darkness itself. The atmosphere of the game and graphics really makes the world vibrant, while the characters are all amazing. From the dialogue to the story, it goes beyond just being solid and keeps you in the whole thing through. A must experience.

Gameplay wise is shines just as well. You can control the darkness, represented by 2 serpent heads, through your mouse and keyboard. Between grabbing enemies, blowing them away, beating them down, throwing them, or performing the gruesome finishers you always feel like it's a fun experience. You start off feeling like a god and progress to the more difficult enemies. It works out really well.

The biggest downside to the game is that it's very short. You can beat the main campaign in a few hours, but you'll end up going through it a couple of times for the fun achievements and maxing out all of the ability trees that carry over to New Game+. You can play in side missions with other characters that lets you experience a parallel story (ie, While Jackie was doing so and so, these guys were doing this to help). They also have dark powers that are all unique. This can be played in single player on lower difficulties or in co-op on higher. The story is the same for all of them, but it's still a great additional mode.

While this game has multiplayer, in my opinion it shines best as a single player experience. The weapons are fun, the enemies are great, the storyline is a masterpiece and the game looks and feels amazing. It's something I feel everyone owes it to themselves to get. The only gripe I could have is that there's no announced sequel or dlc. 10/10 - Get it. It goes on sale for such a low price that it should be a sin not to pick up a copy.

reviewText:
Holy sh*t.

Let me start by saying this, I can't remember the last time a game got me so hooked that I played it solidly to finish in a couple days.

This game probably has one of the most intense stories that I've ever had the pleasure to play through. Playing as Jackie Estacado, head of a mob family you weild the power of the darkness to tear your way through your enemies in pursuit of the culprits behind a sudden attack at a resturant. It may sound like your typical mob family story, but its anything but. Not to mention this game has probably one of my favourite sidekicks of all damn time.

This game throws guns at you to use at yoru disposale but let me tell you this, you should rarely be using them as a primary weapon, with the power of the darkness which takes form as two demon serpents which you control as you see fit, you can brutally rip your enemies, pull their spines through their *ss and eat their hearts out, why would you use a gun.

The gameplay and combat is smooth and at later parts of the game really require you to use your surroundings to your advantage. No matter what difficulty you play on there will be that challenge and that satisfaction of your success.

Now thats not to say this game is without its flaws. The voice of the 'darkness' tries to sound menacing but in all reality, its a little bit dull for a voice you expect the ultimate evil to have. On top of this you can't use your demonic powers in the light, which is a nice touch, but when your getting constantly told by the darkness to 'stay away from the light', especially in places where it can't be helped, it gets really, REALLY annoying.

I also encountered a couple of times where I couldn't actually activate a button or trigger an event because the prompt wouldn't show up, I fixed it by restarting the checkpoints but it took several attempts.

So yes, a fantastic game coupled with fluant gameplay/combat mixed in with an intruiging, albeit irritating ally, the Darkness II is well worth its price. Best part is though? Its only a dollar on humble bundle right now so there is no excuse not to give this a try.

reviewText:
I'll give the developers credit for one thing. The combat mechanics have been vastly improved over the original Darkness game. Everything else however, is a massive disappointment. The original game had an amazing atmosphere and style. It didn't just apply cell shading in a cheap attempt to make it feel more like the comic. Oddly enough, some of the best moments in the original were when nothing was really happening. Sitting down to watch a movie with Jackie's girlfriend, reuniting an old couple in the subway hubworld, or even spotting an old Warner Bros. cartoon on a TV in game. Sadly moments like that are no where to be found in The Darkness 2. Tossing those moments aside, developer Digital Extremes have gone as far as axing most of the original voice cast, with the exception of Mike Patton, who still delivers an amazing performance as The Darkness entity.

When it comes down to it, The Darkness 2 is pretty much another mindless shooter with a Darkness paint job. It's a really good paint job mind you, it's just missing all those things that made the original game special. So if you, like me, have a lot of love for the original. You're probably not going to find what you're looking for here. For those who just want another gore ridden corridor shooter, there are better alternatives, Painkiller: Hell and Damnation for example.

Can't recommend this game. Sorry.

reviewText:
For me, definitely a solid 8-9/10.

Solid arcade mechanics that take a bit to get used to but are ultimately fun and satisfying.
Impactful story full of varying emotion with a surprising amount of character development that actually makes you care about what's going on.
Cell-shaded art style that slightly strays away from the first game's darker colours by adding considerable vibrance to environments.

I very much cared for the characters in the short (around 5 hours long) but satisfying storyline and was compelled to see it through to the end. The emotions experienced in what I thought to be such a dull, depressing game were amazing and I definately felt attached to some of the characters also.

Surprisingly, it left quite an impact on me and it's not a story I'm likely to forget anytime soon.
I would recommend this to anyone who's a fan of arcade shooters, dark, meaningful stories and brutal gameplay.

reviewText:
This game it is not a complete disaster, even though I do not personally recommend it.
It's not recommended only if you've played the original The Darkness on console.

In any case: this is what I call a missed opportunity. The Darkness II tries to continue the adventures of the unlucky Jackie Estacado, tormented by the death of his girlfriend Jenny, with The Darkness itself to spice the things up.
As written in the comic books, Jackie is the carrier of an antique evil force that humans passed on from generations to generations constantly fighting its counterpart, the Light. In this chapter we'll se a mysterious cult who is pursuing him to steal his mystical power. Unfortunately, the plot is the weakest part of the experience, and it is a shame, because the gameplay is satisfying. Being the Darkness is a good experience, you can feel like an overpowered creature who can slaughter and kill everything it breathes. Although there are few powers that  you can play with, they're fun to use. Also the environment interaction is pretty good, in fact you can take various object with your demonic limb and throw them to your foes with enjoyable and squishy results. The game encourages you to do so in many different ways, as you can earn Dark Essence (XP) to unlock powers and abilities.
The gunplay instead, it's sufficient: no recoil, the weapons sound and feel all over the same. The only difference you can tell about them is the fire ratio. It suffers from the modern FPS syndrome: high difficulty = enemies have lots of health points, so going further with the game usually is just trying and failing with a poor challenge. At least there's not regenerating health because you have to eat hearts from dead enemies in order to replenish it.
There is also a limited multiplayer coop mode with 4 characters to choose from with different skills and abilities, but it adds nothing to the experience, it's just another excuse to shoot everything. Maybe this mode was built in order to extend the game length, because the singleplayer campaign is very short (about 6 hours).

Do yourself a favor: if you own a PS3 or Xbox360 go and grab a copy of the first game. You won't be disappointed.

reviewText:
This is a rail-shooter/FPS based on a Top Cow comic book series, in case you didn't already know.

reviewText:
While I have not played the first Darkness game, I am in love with this one. The aesthetic is fantastic and looks great not matter what settings you play on, the gameplay brings something new to the genre of linear shooters, the story is gripping and I had a lot of fun learning the lore of the story in general.

Pros:
- Interesting use of light as a mechanic
- Duel wielding semi-automatic guns
- Interesting story
- Being able to slash people with a shadowy tentacle from hell
- Being able to pick up people and throw them into walls and watching their corpse rag doll onto the ground
- Upgrade system

Cons:
- Game is really linear
- Is fairly basic in terms of how many mechanics it provides

If you want a game to provide you a power trip, this is what this game excels at and I recommend it highly. If you are not seeking a power trip and want to try a new game that has some interesting mechanics and brings something new to the genre, I would still recommend it.

It's a gruesome game and you feel like a dark god of vengence as you go through it, you feel powerful but challenged which is an interesting blend.  You have to eat hearts with the tentacles for health but it doesn't impede your movement in any way, just a cool thing to watch the tentacle reach out and do it while you are shooting.  Oh and your guy is a good guy.  One of the main detractors that kept me from buying the game for a long time was I thought he was this super evil guy that was just killing people for fun, he's a good guy that is getting revenge, like the punisher or max payne. Overall great game.

reviewText:
The Darkness II will NEVER compare to the graces of its predecessor.  The music, sounds, engine technology, feedback system and voice acting / cutscenes of the original are simply impossible to reproduce without Starbreeze at the helm.

With this being said, The Darkness II manages to offer above average gameplay with an incredibly unique aesthetic, excellent engine performance, superbly paced single player and cutscenes of its own caliber.  Cooperative multiplayer is included as well, though this should be viewed more as an after thought (despite the time spent on fleshing out the 4 characters).

If it's ever $15 or less, get it, enjoy it and look forward to a potential sequel.

reviewText:
Darkness 2 is a first person shooter with fantastic story elements, environments, sound and voice acting. The story of Darkness 2 pulls you in very quickly. The cut scenes are in first person, so you feel like you’re right there in the middle of everything. I truly did want to progress in the game because of how involved I got with the plot.

I will preface this review by saying I would VERY HIGHLY RECOMMEND USING A XBOX 360 CONTROLLER More on that later…

Let’s start with gameplay. Being able to control 2 guns and 2 deadly serpents attached at your shoulders at the same time makes for some killer combos and devastating enemy deaths. The game is very brutal with serpent deaths. Tearing off heads and ripping in half is just a taste. Being that the game is called Darkness, you need to stay in the shadows as the light will disable your serpents and make it difficult to see to fire on your enemies. This effect is truly disabling and you will not survive fighting in the light for long. You can collect various amounts of essence by killing enemies which you can trade in for various skills that will improve your character. There is a “skill reset” option so in case you find some skills are not good, you can reset everything for a small essence fee.

Graphics and environments are stylized and really nicely done. It’s a split between comic book and real looking graphics. It fits right in with the story.

Sound and voice acting are top notch. The Italian mob voices are fantastic and each character is unique. It was always a pleasure to hear dialogue back and forth between everyone. This game has a lot going on for in-game sound. It does get fairly noisy at times but that’s just an observation, not a complaint.

Controls…they take getting used to. I tried this game using a mouse and keyboard but I found myself struggling. Switching to a 360 controller instantly corrected everything BUT the learning curve is still moderate. Stick with it and it’ll eventually become pretty natural.

Stability and FPS are rock solid. Never crashed once on Windows 8.1 and got a solid 60fps throughout the game.

Correct blurry view bug
Many times during the game my view would become slightly blurry. Like the game forgot to reset back the focus. The simple fix when that happens was to take a screenshot. It fixed it instantly each time. It did get annoying as sometimes it would happen during intense battles and I’d have to take a second to reach the screenshot key.

Pros
+Graphics, environment, story, gameplay and sound are all very well done
+Solid 60fps
+Brutal enemy deaths
+Solid variety of enemies
+Slight replay value with new game +
+Vendetta missions

Cons
+Controls take getting used to (use 360 controller)
+Shouldn’t be so many unbreakable lights.
+Some erratic graphical glitches throughout the game. But didn’t take away from anything
+Combat can get somewhat boring
+Darkling and Darkness tips can be repetitive

Bottom line is that Darkness 2 is a great and seemingly underrated game.

Final Score:
7.5/10

reviewText:
The Darkness 2 is, as the name implies, pretty ♥♥♥♥ing dark.

You play as Jackie Estacado, a mobster whose special skills have allowed him to rise to the very top of the New York underworld. And by 'special skills,' I am of course referring to the ancient demonic entity that lives within his body.

But when a bunch of cultists show up and try to steal the power away from him (because if an ordinary guy can use it to become king of the Mafia, imagine what someone with actual ambition could do with it), Jackie must use his eldritch abilities, and a veritable ♥♥♥♥load of increasingly large guns, to defend himself and prevent the power from falling into the wrong hands.

I'll be honest, I was surprised by how much I liked this game. I picked it up expecting a standard shooter with a vaguely gothic design aesthetic. What I wasn't expecting was a genuinely inventive and unique game with solid gameplay and some smart ideas bubbling under the surface. There are some very creative moments throughout the campaign, first as Jackie explores some strange locations, and then later when the demonic presence starts to drive him insane. The ending also qualifies for the 'Holy ♥♥♥♥ing Christ' award of totally unexpected story turns.

The gameplay is the standard gory shooter, but with the twist of dark and brutal abilities. You have two demonic tentacles which can pick up and throw things independant of your two gun-hands, which led to several situations where I was fighting two battles at once- a mid-range skirmish with a pair of SMGs, and also a long-range stand-off in which I was lobbing sharp objects and spikes at snipers.

You also get health by eating hearts that you tear out of dead bodies, which means the only way to get your way out of a tight spot is to use progressively riskier tactics to kill enemies and regain the upper hand.

Overall, it's a surprisingly enjoyable game with some creative uses of mechanics to craft a campaign that is not only fun to play, but fun as an experience.
Final score: 8/10.

reviewText:
Short version with 0 spoliers:  The Darkness II is a good but short game.






Long version possibly containing spoilers:  On the brightside if you're like me, you didn't play The Darkness and just happened to come across The Darkness II while it was on sale and decided it would be worth a play.  I opened the game with kind of low expectations because it just look liked Hatred with a bit more of a story behind it with demons and ♥♥♥♥.  Little did I know that I would be hearing a lot of familiar voices from Mafia II.  I'll start it off by talking a bit about the controls in this game, I assume the game was meant to be operated with a controller because the attacking with darkness via the mouse is very clunky, but not clunky to the point that the game is made easy, otherwise it controls like a typical FPS.  The integration of The Darkness made the gameplay more interesting than the typical FPS luckily.  The graphics aren't even bad considering the 2012 release period.  Getting more into the story element part of the review, I have to say that the storyline took me a bit by surprise, it's not as emotional as it could be given the situation but otherwise the dialogue is well written and is even at some parts, humorous.  The little sidekick you get is probably one of my favorite parts of the game, aside from the intense gore which isn't even really that intense but it's definitely what drove me through the game.  One part in particular which is after you finish killing a boss.  Now to the one but small point that kind of bothered me, turns out this game is super short.  I beat the whole main story in one hour, there is side coop stuff you can do with friends and ♥♥♥♥ but I, a friendless ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, really don't care about that now do I?  Eh small complaint, still a good game worth checking out.

reviewText:
The Darkness 2 is, as the name implies, pretty ♥♥♥♥ing dark.

You play as Jackie Estacado, a mobster whose special skills have allowed him to rise to the very top of the New York underworld. And by 'special skills,' I am of course referring to the ancient demonic entity that lives within his body.

But when a bunch of cultists show up and try to steal the power away from him (because if an ordinary guy can use it to become king of the Mafia, imagine what someone with actual ambition could do with it), Jackie must use his eldritch abilities, and a veritable ♥♥♥♥load of increasingly large guns, to defend himself and prevent the power from falling into the wrong hands.

I'll be honest, I was surprised by how much I liked this game. I picked it up expecting a standard shooter with a vaguely gothic design aesthetic. What I wasn't expecting was a genuinely inventive and unique game with solid gameplay and some smart ideas bubbling under the surface. There are some very creative moments throughout the campaign, first as Jackie explores some strange locations, and then later when the demonic presence starts to drive him insane. The ending also qualifies for the 'Holy ♥♥♥♥ing Christ' award of totally unexpected story turns.

The gameplay is the standard gory shooter, but with the twist of dark and brutal abilities. You have two demonic tentacles which can pick up and throw things independant of your two gun-hands, which led to several situations where I was fighting two battles at once- a mid-range skirmish with a pair of SMGs, and also a long-range stand-off in which I was lobbing sharp objects and spikes at snipers.

You also get health by eating hearts that you tear out of dead bodies, which means the only way to get your way out of a tight spot is to use progressively riskier tactics to kill enemies and regain the upper hand.

Overall, it's a surprisingly enjoyable game with some creative uses of mechanics to craft a campaign that is not only fun to play, but fun as an experience.
Final score: 8/10.

reviewText:
(Note: I didn't play the first The Darkness game nor do I have experience with The Darkness comic books)

At its best The Darkness II is a very stylish game. The comic book origins of this title really come out in a positive way in that regard. Sadly the gameplay does not live up to the presentation aspect of this title.

At the very best you can call The Darkness II an above average shooter. It does nothing special which might sound weird considering how you basically are a semi-god demon monster with tentacles coming out of you ready to rip enemies and the envinroment alike apart. It's just very basic under the shiny shell. You're not really encouraged to utilize your demonic skills and when you do it just doesn't feel very cool.

Naturally darkness is weak to light which brings us to a very frustrating gameplay mechanic. Remember how everyone loves getting hit by flashbangs in shooters? Me neither. The Darkness II manages to take this to another level. Light makes you incapable of using your demon skills which in practice means whatever plan you had with impaling an enemy with that spear-like object you can forget. The real pain starts when enemies start using light against you. This results in many chaotic moments where you just have no idea where to shoot to regain some level of control over the game. The blinding effect of light is way overdone and will make you feel frustrated. When you being the badass mob leader demon you are have to stop every time coming to a new area to snipe off lightbulbs with your pistol you know something is not done right. To top this off the game has a bug which frequently makes motion blur reverse". What this means is that everytime the motion blur should be off it's on and vice versa. It's not enough to destroy the experience but it's annoying.

The story is The Darkness II's best part. It's not magnificient but it will keep you interested. Characters are solid with a few really standing out. That said I felt very unsatisfied with the ending. As a stand-alone product it doesn't really work.

After about 7 hours of singleplayer campaign you don't have much to do. You can hunt down relics (with some really interesting descriptions as a reward I have to say!) or try a harder difficulty level. The game also features the "mandatory online element" where four of your friends take on separate missions from main story. With no real story I had absolutely no motivation in trying my hands at those the gameplay being mediocre. If you want a multiplayer co-op shooter I'm sure you can think of better ways of spending your time and money.

After all the complaining you might think I hate the game but this is not the case at all. Beyond the presentation it's just not anything special. Mediocrity is not a crime and I'd say The Darkness is definitely worth it if you can find a great deal. At anywhere close to the full price I wouldn't consider it."

reviewText:
The Darkness II is emblematic of so many of the worst narrative and design concepts of gaming as a medium.

It’s a game so obsessed with its own mythos, so completely devoid of self-awareness, and so appallingly misogynistic that it is often actively painful to witness. The entirety of The Darkness II seems designed around alliterative bullet points: “guns, girls, and gore.” In many ways then this isn’t terribly different from so many shooters, but where The Darkness II sets itself apart is in how much it revels in its own stupidity and filth.

It’s going to be important later on in this review, so just so we’re all caught up let’s quickly run through the basic premise behind The Darkness II: brooding protagonist has nothing to live for; girlfriend gives him purpose; girlfriend is killed to get back at protagonist; protagonist has nothing to live for and decides to kill everyone. Somewhere in there is also the fact that our protagonist, mafia kingpin Jackie Estacado, has a demon (the eponymous Darkness) living inside him which gives him superpowers and mostly makes him invincible. From here on events unfold as they typically do, with the introduction of a cult hell-bent on taking Jackie’s darkness (because that’s what cults do) causing all sorts of chaos, as Jackie all the while holds up inside his head lamenting the loss of his girlfriend and showing emotions™.

Though its stereotypical setup might lead you to believe otherwise, The Darkness II’s biggest problem isn’t in its rudimentary plot (though that’s definitely one of them) but in how its only means of creating conflict and motivation for its characters is through violence toward women. Jackie’s girlfriend, Jenny, is fridged before the prologue is finished (a carryover from the last game) and from that point on The Darkness II kills literally every single female character in the game for the sake of motivating Jackie, all while neglecting to give them even the smallest bit of personality, as ultimately their only reason for inclusion (beyond to be fridged) is to be objectified and tortured.

What’s possibly even worse than the way The Darkness II treats women is in how it attempts to mask its misogyny under faux-emotional maturity and narrative sophistication. Developer Digital Extremes dedicates a not-insignificant amount of time to attempting to humanize the relationship between Jackie and Jenny, but because Jenny exists merely as a narrative prop with all the personality of a perverted body pillow these segments feel like little more than gross reminders of how one sided and shallow their relationship actually is. It doesn’t help that Jackie is something beyond unlikable with a penchant for juvenile philosophy, as he sits in the dark gun in hand and recites odes to his own amorality. The Darkness II was never a game with a penchant for subtlety, but its writing is so horrendous and convenient that it can’t even scrape by as merely clichéd, but instead doubles down on its tropes, on its misogyny, on its pornographic love of meaningless violence, and then tries to sell it to you as mature storytelling.

Some might say this is just staying true to The Darkness’ comic book roots, but justifying The Darkness II’s narrative disaster through its mirroring of another work does little but damn them both. And to that point there is little about The Darkness II that speaks to its awareness of the tropes it’s employing, as it is so abundantly self-serious that it is impossible to enjoy it as knowingly dumb or comically grotesque the way one might enjoy a B-movie. In the few cases where The Darkness II tries to introduce some levity to its proceedings it predictably punches down, with sexist and ableist jabs that are neither clever nor shocking, but just as cheap and untasteful as the rest of the game.

And low and behold if this isn’t as exceedingly routine a shooter as its narrative deserves. The Darkness II’s main mechanical hook is using your two demon arms in conjunction with more ordinary guns to create a sort of synergistic ultraviolence, but in application your demonic appendages are little more than glorified swords and grappling hooks. There was a lot of room for The Darkness II to create interesting encounters focused around forcing you to think creatively with the one thing that sets this apart from any other shooter, but The Darkness II is wholly and unapologetically married to its power fantasy mundanity, and so you are left with room after room of decidedly uninteresting grunts to tear your way through as if the thrill of watching your demon arms rip a man in half is enough to make combat interesting.

The Darkness II’s demon arms reminded me a lot of Bioshock’s plasmids, but where Bioshock used its plasmids to setup interesting dynamics between you and your enemies, The Darkness II is focused on nothing but accommodating as aggressive a playing style as possible. And that’s not inherently bad, but there is nothing about how The Darkness II plays that makes that aggression satisfying. The shooting is loose, your arms are overpowered, the enemies are tedious and ordinary, and you’re constantly being funneled down the tightest of corridors. The Darkness II tries to counteract this by implementing a kill based scoring system reminiscent of Bulletstorm, but it lacks the depth and creativity that made kills in that game so entertaining, settling here for a narrow range of possibilities which mostly serve to distinguish between gun and darkness kills.

The Darkness II’s mechanics would feel like a missed opportunity if the entirety of the framework surrounding them wasn’t so unsalvageable. The Darkness II is a game reeking of the worst sorts of narrative based sexism, marrying its violent tendencies with misogynistic conveniences, and the sort of discriminating carelessness that video games so often try to pass off as a sign of their maturity. To the contrary The Darkness II is one of the least innovative and sophisticated games I have played in a very long time, seeming to exist for the very sake of regressing videogames back to a time when nobody questioned why every female character has enormous breasts or why they are constantly getting kidnapped.

You can read more of my writing on Kritiqal[kritiqal.com].

reviewText:
OK, why was I so disappointed with this game? Three main points spoiled this game for me. I won't go on about graphics, they're fine. Decent engine, decent artists etc. Game mechanics were fine. The menu system was a little annoying but you get used to that. Music was typically horrible but thankfully you can turn it off unlike some games(yes Halo 4, I'm talking about you) So what didn't I like? Read on.

Firstly, cinematics...lots and lots of cinematics. The annoying kind where you can't move and the characters talk seemingly forever when all they have to do is say, 'go out the door and shoot everyone you see.'. You can hardly travel 100 meters without being dragged into some scripted action sequence or some long boring dialogue. Judging by the amount of positive reviews this game receives I assume most people don't mind this. I don't understand. I find it very tedious. Don't get me wrong, I like storylines. I'm happy to sit and watch little cinematics every now and then. I just hate the game being interrupted every 5 minutes just so someone can tell you to walk down some stairs or whatever. OK, finished gripe no.1

Second gripe; the demon, serpent, tentacle, ♥♥♥♥♥ things. I assumed they were something you could bring up to use when you needed them. Nope, they're there the whole time. Fine if you like that sort of thing, IE great big dangly appendages cluttering up the screen, and I understand that some people do like that sort of thing, just not me. Oh, and apart from their basic intrusiveness, they're just silly. A gangster with tentacles, spare me please.

Thirdly, the sidekick. Again, some people obviously like annoying little halfwit sidekicks running around saying annoying half witted things. I just happen to not. The last half hour of my abortive attempt at playing this game was spent shooting it. The only joy I had in this game was discovering that you can shoot the sidekick, though regrettably he does regenerate.

So there you have it. I wanted to like this game. I loved Sandman and Hellblazer and other stuff back in the day. I knew it would be silly. It's graphic novel/comic book type horror, of course it's going to be silly. Unfortunately excessive cinematics, non-retractable tentacles and a sidekick modelled on a brain damaged teenage metal head made this game unplayable for me. Sorry Digital Extremes. I tried.

reviewText:
Before I start I just want to say that the combat system in this game is quite fun.

Now that I said that let's begin. First off the FOV slider doesn't go high enough for me but I like to play on a FOV of 90 or higher so that is most likely not going to affect you. Secondly the amount of dialogue vs combat feels like 50/50 due to it being quite lengthy and often unskippable when it is not a cutscene. Thirdly one of the mechanics in the game is that bright areas remove your supernatural powers. This would be an interesting mechanic except it makes the game often annoying due to you being in the middle of a firefight and then lose your tentacles so you have to look up and take out the light while being shot. Also there are lights which you can only take out when you follow the wiring to a generator which is annoying as you often have to pass through the light to get to it.

These problems I could handle and are only minor mistkes but it was when I reached the vent crawling part of the game which I stopped. What happened was there was some glitch where you could not fit through unless you jumped at a specific angle. After about five minutes of this I stopped out of frustration.


Of course I advise you to also read other peoples reviews so that you can get a better view of this game to see if it is for you.

reviewText:
A game befitting of its name, this is a dark and gruesome game.
The game is taken from a comic book series with the same name.

Graphics are cell shader and do a good job paying homage to the comic books it sprang from.

The story is a highlight of the game, its clever with lots of humor (dark humor ;) and pokes fun at the gangster genres and overall reminded me of Spec Ops the Line.

The game played well and shot well, which was good, but enemies were boring and the same models were just reskinned throughout each level. The best weapon in the game were the black holes; they were always graphically pleasing and satisying way to eleminate baddies.

I don't recommend the darkness 2 because of its over the top voilence.
I got tired of the repeated zoom-ins on 'darkness kills' (the darkness isn't just a metaphor for the darkside inside the proganist its also a evil spirit that manifests itself with tentacles that act as a send set of arms for your character).  The darkness kills are necessary to regenearte health/ammo but are acted out in such repeated brutality that you get tired of  beheadings and characters torn in half directly in front of the in-game camera.

reviewText:
Overall, The Darkness 2 is a good game, but it has a variety of frustrating details that make the game much less fun, and generall my willingness to pay attention to the story.

1. Controls - There are several boss fights as well as a bunch of ordinary encounters that require you to quickly move out of the way or dodge something. The problem is that you move like a pregnant boat. This isn't really that much worse than a lot of first person shooter games, but those games don't want you to dodge.

2. Nonsense - You can run through the game getting blasted by shotguns and machine guns and survive. I don't have a problem with this. After all, in the context of the story you should be able to. The problem is that whenever the story wants you for some reason a quick flash or lights or a shotgun blast put you on the ground unable to move.

3. Lights - I really do like the mechanic that you can't use any of your powers in the light--that is the way that it is in the comic after all--but that game randomly desides that some lights can't be destroyed. So, you spend a great deal of the game destroying one light after another only to be held up in the level by a light with a metal grate over it. Annoying.

4. Story - The story deviates significantly from the comic, but that isn't necessarily a bad thing. There are however two main problems with how the story is told in this game. First, there are a greate deal of boring dialogue that you have to pay attention to, to have any understanding of what is happening in the story. This becomes grating. Second, the story relys very heavily on common tropes. Vengence for the murder of your girlfriend. Vengence for *spoiler*'s murder. A dark broodin man of violence, fighting his inner demons. It's been done.

It tells the story of a mob boss Jackie Estacado and his tormented life living with a dark god / demon known as The Darkness" which basically grants him immortality but slowly draining his humanity.

reviewText: Ok, the game itself its quite good. It has an amazing story, especially for a more or less Mafia tale, the characters are all top notch, and all the lines are well preformed. The graphics look pretty good, with some bad textures from time to time, but its all cell shaded, which makes it look a lot like Borderlands. But that would only be if Borderlands was bloody. No joke, there was less gore in saving private Ryan. Limbs get torn off, people get impaled, and its all in this bloody mess. Which is good, by the way. Anyway, the gameplay is very arcade like shoot em up, with your demon arm to help impale people. Even on the lowest difficulty setting, its still a hard game, coming from a seasoned DkS2 vet,and well, ya. The only gripe I have with the gameplay is that ammo is semi-scare in early game, which well, just feels weird in an FPS.\nOverall, if you find the game on a sale, pick up up without hesitation.\nIf you dont, well, here comes one of my only gripes. Single Player length. It will last only about 6 hours on Med. I get that its not that big of a deal, but well, for a game with not to much replay value...I mean, it does have a coop mode, but when I picked it up, the coop was dead.

1. Good graphics.
